reviewText:
Early Access Review

At its core, Crypt of the NecroDancer consists of one simple premise: move to the rhythm. The action unfolds according to the unholy beat of the Necrodancer - you must move with it, attack with it, dodge the enemy onslaught with it. The literal pulse of Cadence's heart drives a deadly crypt and the twisted monsters within.

But underneath it is something more. Dig deeper, and the player uncovers a surprisingly deep gameplay experience, especially for one still in Early Access. Each weapon type sports a unique attack pattern. A cavalcade of items and equipment provides benefits ranging from immediate health recovery to phasing through walls or limiting the number of enemies. Spells can give you an upper hand against the thralls, freezing them in place or blasting them to ashes with a fiery bolt. Shrines, hidden shops, secret enemies, multiple playable characters... they all contribute to an experience unlike most other rhythm games you've played.

Crypt of the NecroDancer falls into the roguelike" genre and as such you'll see many of its usual trappings: procedural dungeons
hoursPlayed: bombs and consumables
voteText: etc. What sets this apart from other similar games
helpfulPercent: aside from the rhythm aspect
votesHelpful: is that luck only plays a minimal factor in your success. Every level and every enemy is balanced in a way that completing a run from start to finish without ever upgrading from the starting dagger is entirely possible
votesTotal: and in fact has been done multiple times. If you're into other roguelike games there is a lot here for you to love and be familiar with. I
votesFunny: for one
commentsCount: never cared much for the genre. Games like Spelunky and The Binding of Isaac I've played a few times
column16: but ultimately I grew tired of them. 120+ hours later
column17: Crypt of the NecroDancer has me completely hooked.\n\nOne of its biggest strengths is its absolutely stellar soundtrack composed by the well-known Danny Baranowsky. It was a smart move to focus the gameplay around this music - it provides just the right atmosphere and you'll find yourself bobbing your head to the beat as you play without even noticing it. One of the other aspects that really drew me in was that the game feels completely fair. You don't need one specific item to get a good run
column18: and you don't need lucky shops or good spawns to make it to the end. Skill and familiarity with the enemies can carry you 99% of the way. Learning enemy behaviors and discovering new items become fun exercises. If you die
column19: you know exactly what mistake you made and learn to avoid that for the next run. You can play with a keyboard
column20: a controller
column21: or even a dance pad
column22: and you can even add your own music into the levels! The game also has a welcoming community and great forums you can visit to seek advice or share your latest victory.\n\nThere's even still more to come! One more "zone" will be added to the game
column23: there will be more boss fights
column24: as well as the possibility for more items
column25: equipment
column27: etc. Even in its "alpha" state Crypt of the NecroDancer is a deep and rewarding experience
column28: and I personally can't wait to see more!"
column32: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
At its core, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a rouge-like dungeon crawler. However, as you become more invested in the game's unique on-the-beat movement system, you'll begin to realize that NecroDancer is much more than that! Strategy comes into play when dealing with enemies with increasingly complex movement systems, especially when you get the urge to compete for a top spot on the speedrun and gold high school leaderboards in each Daily Challenge.

DannyB's soundtrack for this game is fantastic and somehow hasn't gotten boring to me even after hours and hours playing the game. There's also always the option to enchant the Crypt with your own MP3s with ease!

The story is surprisingly deep and well thought out - cutscenes are quick but pack a lot of meaning. They flesh out the lore of the NecroDancer very well, and offer a very satisfying resolution that ties up all loose ends.

Brace Yourself Games handled Early Access like champs - there was and still is a huge amount of community involvement, and I've seen many community suggested features be implemented!

Crypt of the NecroDancer WELL WELL WELL worth the cost. Buy it NOW if you have any interest! It's easy to pick up, but hard to master!

P.S.: for any musicians out there, I can say that this game has definitely improved my rhythm-keeping skills!
voteText: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yep, it's a roguelike played via DDR. Dance pads compatible but not required. It may technically be in Early Access but I'd never know, the game seems pretty complete as is and I keep getting my ♥♥♥ handed to me before I can even clear Zone 2 (there being 4 zones at present).

The gameplay is pretty self-explanatory once you've gone through the quick tutorial, but is ever a matter of reflexes and quick thinking to keep yourself in one piece. Enemies are deviously varied to give you all manner of headaches to fight in conjunction with one another. Diamonds acquired through play are spent in the hub to unlock new equipment to appear in chests (as well as some passive upgrades like health). Rooms are available to help you practice fighting against specific enemies and bosses, and one character is available to let you just play the game as a regular turn-based roguelike. There's a local co-op mode of some sort too, hell if I know how that works. Hardcore mode is available for a no-upgrades run, and there's a daily one-shot hardcore challenge available, ala Spelunky.

There are a few minor sticking points.
1) You can import your own music for any of the levels you like, which is fantastic, except when the automatic beat detection--which, granted, is impressively accurate on the whole--doesn't work quite right and there's no way to attempt a manual fix.
2) The game doesn't require you to keep on the beat perfectly, there's a fair leeway in the timing and you can miss beats if you don't mind losing your current cash multiplier (that is, unless you've invoked a risk shrine); this is open to some strategizing with skipping a beat to ready yourself for an enemy, but there's no actual control function for 'skip beat' and so you're left waiting for the input grace period between beats for enemies to make their move, after which it's hard to get right back into the rhythm.
3) There's no count in" between levels at all
date: so to keep your multiplier up you have to start moving again before you've even processed what's immediately around you or what the new rhythm actually is.\n4) Practice rooms for monsters are great
recommended: but having to defeat a monster or boss once during normal play to unlock them seems a bit counterintuitive.\n\nMinor gripes. Very solid soundtrack
hoursPlayed: very solid gameplay. Would probably be a HELL of a party game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I have to admit, I fell in love with the opening sequence. It's the perfect blend of music, plot, voice acting and a beat to get me hyped all the hell when I start it up. DROP DEAD!

The game is really enjoyable. It's a Roguelike, but it feels less dependent on luck, and more on skill and planning then most others. I don't generally feel like I was screwed too hard when I die; As far as I can see it, you should be able to clear the game without getting hit, or at least close, if you're god-like at pattern recognition.

Every enemy has it's own pattern, which, I can't believe the game didn't refer to as it's unique Dance. Maybe it's too corny. As Cadence (oh, there's the corniness. Works, though.) remarks, 'learn that, and they'll never harm you.' (something like that.)

I think the one negative I've had in dealing with the game is in using items and spells. It's not impossible, but it takes a good deal getting used to. You only have 4 keys, the 4 directions. To use items, you combine them. Ex, an apple is Up+Left, or whatnot. Keeping your combo going while using them very rarely works out for me in the heat of a battle.

But, even then, you can bind those combinations to other keys, if you like. Up+Left could be bound to Ctrl, or Shift, or Left trigger.

Yes, it works with gamepads. Personally, I bound XBAY and the Dpad to all directions applicable. If your one hand gets tired, switch to the other! Or, if you have a Left+Right item, it works well using both hands, I find, so it's Left+B instead.

Aaaaanyway. Graphics are fine. Gameplay is fun (first level's tempo is a liiitle slow for my taste), and the feeling on beating a boss is rewarding. King Conga and his Zombie Conga Lines (yes) confused the hell out of me the first time, but when you learn it, it's just plain fun.

In short, I love installing large screen televisions in doghouses, and Crypt of the NecroDancer is a good game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crypt of the NecroDancer is half turn-based dungeon crawler with randomly-generated dungeons. The other half of the game is rhythm: each dungeon floor has a unique music track with a visually emphasized steady beat. Your moves are (ideally) made to that beat. Enemies also move to the beat, so the pace at which things happen is determined by the music. Having a steady rhythm locks the participant into a timeframe in which to act, not unlike speed chess or the rate at which a block lowers in Tetris. By removing the infinite time in which a player could decide which move is most optimal in your traditional turn-based dungeon excursions, the game becomes instead one of relying almost wholly on experience. After a while, experience becomes instinct, leading to creative leaps of strategy made entirely in the moment, in the space between the game’s figurative and literal heartbeats.

You play as Cadence, a headstrong delver who - through an unfortunate combination of a terminal fall and an evil NecroDancer stealing her still-beating heart - must now travel down multiple dungeon floors, fighting monsters and finding useful items. You technically don’t have to move to the beat, but not doing so will cause you to lose a vital multiplier that increases how many coins you earn from defeated monsters. The higher the multiplier, the more likely you can afford powerful weapons and items found in dungeon shops. You know when you’re moving to the beat, because the dungeon floor starts pulsing with light, making it your very own little dungeon rave.

There is very little randomness to the combat in Crypt of the NecroDancer. Everything behaves according to very set rules. You move into a monster to attack it, different weapons change the shape of your attack. If an enemy moves into a square you were trying to move to, you’ll take damage instead. Certain enemies take advantage of your urge to rush in, waiting a beat before moving, or moving in interesting patterns. Monsters have unique little dance animations, their movement sounds become a part of the melody of what’s happening on the screen. These sounds are often a clue to defeating them. As you delve deeper, the music becomes faster, the monster patterns more complex. The game is ingenious, fun in ways indescribable unless you’re there, in the moment, taken by the rhythm and amazed at how well you’re doing.

You can use your own MP3s for the soundtrack, and there’s even a DDR mode for use with a dance pad. The DDR mode makes a game a bit easier so you don’t kill yourself. There’s permanent progression via character upgrades, like a health increase and magic spells, unlocked by collecting diamonds.

The music is being provided by the excellent Danny Baranowsky (Super Meat Boy, Canabalt, Binding of Isaac, Desktop Dungeons).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While the game is still in Beta, what has been completed is worthwhile.

Necrodancer is a rhythm, turn-based, roguelike. It can be played with just directional keys, so dancepad friendly.  You move your character  to the beats of Danny Baranowsky (Super Meat Boy, Binding of Isaac) as you make your way through 3 (4 upon release) zones, each containing 3 levels and a boss fight.

There are currently 7 playable characters offering various challenges with a variety of weapons and items to utilize. Floors are randomly generated and you can race for better times or complete to get the highest score. The game is challenging, but fair so when you die, it was probably your fault. The game provides a training feature so you can practice against any enemy and hone your strategies. Other features include a daily challenge, seeded runs, and creating your own levels. You can even customize the music that plays as well as mod in game sprites.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NecroDancer is a great rhythm-based Rogue-like where you take turns to the beat of the music.  Miss a beat, everything around you takes a turn anyway.  At first it sounds weird to not have all the time in the world to plan a move in an RL, but NecroDancer makes it work with basic patterns to all creatures.  The main challenge is balancing keeping the beat up with putting yourself in a good position to deal with whatever comes at you.  You need either quick decision-making or good muscle memory from repeated plays to deal with complex situations.

Unreservedly recommend it once the game is completed.  $15 for early access is alright, but you'll probably have to be interested in the concept beforehand to feel fully happy about your $15.

reviewText:
This game combines rhythm and roguelike like fried chicken and waffles. If you haven't experienced them together, you think it's a bizarre combo that won't mesh well. Then you try it and you wonder why you haven't had the two together before. Where has this magical combo been your entire life?

Gimmick aside, the game is still beautifully designed. The enemies all have tells and literally have choreographed attacks. Everything gives signs before the action takes place, much like many roguelikes. It's just that this game took that dance and set it to a kickin' soundtrack. You can even practice against enemies without needing to throw yourself into the deep end to figure out their tells.
Even the characters are more upbeat and lively than your average roguelike. The little things, like how they greet NPCs (shyly VS boldly VS force of habit) and their surprised reactions to teleportation make them seem less like digital avatars and more like humans. A little detail that adds a lot of magic to the game.

[edit] THE STORY. Add the story to another fantastic bit of this game. Only frustrating bit is how hard it is to complete story mode, but hey, it's a roguelike. That's to be expected from the genre.

TL;DR - A wonderfully charming game that blends two very different genres in a lovingly-designed piece. I strongly recommend you pick up the game and the soundtrack!

reviewText:
Crypt of the Necrodancer is a cross of both rhythm game and turned based  RPG in where you have to move along to the beat of the song and keep a steady rhythm to get a higher combo count. Every note counts as a turn and missing a note resets your combo as well as costs you a turn. This is a game in where you must have must both quick reflexes and foresight since you don't have much time to think. Your enemies also move along to the beat of the song so you can estimate how long it will take them to reach you and plan accordingly. Movement is grid based so you move square by square and the only buttons you will need during the game are the arrow keys. You attack by moving next to an enemy and hitting the arrow direction they are in and stranger still is that you use your bombs by holding the down and left arrow. There are also spells and other items that are activated by holding the up and right keys. As you can no doubt tell this is a rather strange control scheme and it does take some time to get used to. It is a strange gameplay concept to explain properly and there is nothing else like it on the market so I would suggest looking up some gameplay videos to see if this is your cup of tea.

The levels are split up into 4 zones accessible via the hub-world where you can also purchase new items and weaponry that randomly spawns in the level once purchased. To purchase these items you will need diamonds which are semi rare collectibles scattered around the levels. Once you either die or pass that zone you will be tossed to the hub-world and will be able to spend your diamonds. Be wary though as entering any level will reset your diamonds back to zero so always make sure to spend them before heading back into the action. Another important collectible found in levels is gold which can be used to purchase unlocked weapons and items from shops. If you don't have any gold when you find a shop you can also blow up the golden walls of the shop to collect the debris and buy your items that way, the shopkeeper won't mind his walls being blown up funnily enough. One of the really neat things about this game is that the levels are destructible and you start off with a shovel that allows you to create your own paths through them and search for hidden goodies. There is a time limit for each level however, so if the song finishes you are immediately dropped down to the next level via a trapdoor. Each zone  has three levels that lead to a boss fight and you will want to be well equipped when you face one of them.

Bosses are randomly generated so you will not face the same boss each attempt but all of them will take quite a bit of skill to defeat. One of the easier ways to handle bosses is to pick up a spear if you are lucky enough to find one as it can attack from two blocks away meaning you can attack it from a safe place. That is easier said than done however since missing a beat will cost you a turn which can have dire consequences. You need to have a good rhythm at all times and that is very hard to do when you have to press two keys at the same time to use an item or spell. Keeping an unbroken rhythm also makes any gold you collect be worth much more, so the better you are at doing that the higher your chances of survival. If you find a key and save someone from a cage you will unlock a new character which play differently from our original heroine. One of them fights by only using bombs, another character can't attack but all exits are unlocked and one of the characters even gets rid of the rhythm part of the game entirely, allowing you to move whenever you want and take your time. There are quite major changes to the gameplay from character to character which makes this game's replayablity really high.

Crypt of the Necrodancer is brutal and you will be dying a lot until you unlock some better gear with diamonds. It has randomly generated levels so learned the pattern of them is not an option and it is more than happy to toss out a bunch of enemies. Learning how to fight each enemy is integral to be able to hold your own as some will roll toward you on sight leaving you with little time to move but hitting it on time will send it spiraling back to whence it came. Weapons also have their own quirks to them such as crossbows having to be reloaded but give you great range and rapiers will cause your character to rush in to attack an enemy two blocks away. Finding armor will lower the amount of damage you take and a torch will increase your view distance. This game is much more complex than it may appear and knowledge will be your greatest strength in these funky crypts. On the hubworld, the Beastmaster’s area allows you to pick any enemy you like and practice against them to your hearts content. It is not unlocked from the beginning as he is locked in a cage and must be freed in order to show up in the hubworld. There is a story but it is very forgettable and unimportant.

As is expected of a rhythm game the music is very catchy and fit the tongue in cheek feel of the game very well. Each stage has its own unique song and if you ever get tired of them there are a few other remixed soundtracks you can choose from, such as a Metal version. You can even use your own music but the notes don't match up at all to the songs making it very hard to keep a steady rhythm. It is an extra option so I can't really knock it but I can't imagine too many people wanting to use it. Crypt of the Necrodancer supports Steam Workshop and there are quite a bit of mods to keep you entertained such as one that changes your character into Hatsune Miku and even one that overhauls the whole game to have a Mario Bros aesthetic. There is plenty of content in the base game and the levels being randomly generated insures that you will have a different experience each playthrough. What it ultimately comes down to is if you like the strange gameplay on offer here and would like to once again suggest looking up a gameplay video. I'd imagine it would be much more fun to use a dancepad and a large TV to play this but using the keyboard works well enough too. Crypt of the Necrodancer is a unique experience you can't get anywhere else and tons of fun to boot.

reviewText:
Beatgames (or rhythm games) tend to be very hard at first, but when you practice, you can literally see your improvement. Although this game is not a pure beatgame, it has the full characteristics of one. The concept of two different game genres put into one is incredible, but it is just EPIC when the execution of it is perfect.

The soundtrack of this game is simply amazing. I've never really had a taste for electronic music or jazz, but the stuff they put into this game definitely made me change my mind. The way they've designed everything, I think, was so you, the player, could jam to any music that would hit you. Every moving object in the game has an animation that moves to the rhythm of the BPM (beats per minute; determines how fast a song is) of the song, the shopkeepers' singing is just perfect, and the rest of the sound effects (voices, attacks, monsters) flow so astoundingly. Sometimes I play this game just because I want to listen to the soundtrack. Custom music is a plus, and I have not found any errors working with it so far. It has it's own BPM detection that works fine.

Randomly generated-ness (well that's rogue-like, isn't it?) makes this game never get old. The story mode is of moderate length, and surprisingly, or at least, for me, I have gotten tied to the characters and I have grown to have sympathy for them! If you don't have a thing for rogue-like games, this will surely change your mind (That's what had happened to me).

The pixel art is adorable, and the character concept art for those monsters are.. dark and horrifying. Think you have a slow/old computer and can't run this game? This game ran at 60 fps on mine, so you're fine. (In case you didn't get it, my computer is very bad.)

When you first start playing, the thing that you need to remember is to never give up. If you die five times in a row, you should either take a break for a while and come back to the game later or keep playing. You will  see that improvement and it will just feel amazing. You actually feel accomplished about something, which is what very few games are able to do.

As for going into more depth about the gameplay, no need for that. It is all for you to discover yourself. But here's something to remember: although the content of this game doesn't seem that abundant, trust me. It was way more stuff than you think. They also have a level editor after you complete the game (or should I say, a fraction of the game [Note what I said to remember]), so you can upload your creations to the Steam Workshop that is connected to the game or just play them alone. Nothing wrong with that.

To sum it up, this game deserves every one of those awards that you see to the right. If not, more than that. This review cannot express how much I enjoy this game. It is one of the most unique and unforgettable gaming experiences ever. Get this game if you're looking for something new to enjoy.

Highly Recommended
Also, sorry if I have any grammar/typing errors. I did not read this over.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game. A lot. Now, take into account what most of the high-rated reviews say, because I agree with them. But what I'm going to touch on is something specific that I find most interesting and perhaps wholly unique about this game. Put simply, it reminds me of chess. In fact, one of the final boss room types is a chess set, which you can see briefly in the trailer, but that's beside the point. All enemies have set actions (or perhaps reactions), and will always make them according to the rhythm and how you move. For instance, the red dragon will move once every two beats toward you unless you are any distance directly to the left or right of him, in which case he will shoot a row of fire. The goblins will run away if you approach them, but pursue if you move away from them.

Now, normally, if you had all the time you needed, you could plan out a perfect attack and kill everything without taking damage, but in this game, you have to move with the beat. You have to think quickly if you want to work your way out of a tricky situation. When you die, you feel like it was your mistake and the game had not cheated you, which is generally the case (though there is a small chance of the game generating an absurdly difficult enemy encounter). Even so, due to the random generation, it is possible to find a good weapon or food early on, making giving you an advantage. I always hope for an awesome weapon, but sometimes find myself doing surprisingly well with just a standard dagger. It's action/strategy/cool music-y rhythm/rogue-like at its finest.

Absolutely amazing. I never thought there would ever be a roguelike-rythm game, but here we are, and it's executed in such a way that this will probably end up being my favorite game of the year. The game is played using just arrow keys for movement and item usage, and it works really well.

The game appears as a standard roguelike dungeon crawler; you make tactical choices in turn-based style battles, find equipment and try to battle your way through dungeons. The difference is that the game focuses on forcing the player to keep in step with the beat of the song for movement and actions (traditionally what you'd consider to be turns")
date: giving the player a bonus in gold which can be used to buy equipment if done without flaw. Failing to move with the beat will result in a missed action while all the enemies take a turn and losing this bonus.\n\nI don't think I've ever played an RPG so easy to get into

reviewText:
Rhythm games and dungeon crawlers seem like they'd be incompatible, but Crypt of the NecroDancer makes the two work together. You have to move and act to the beat of the music, so you must assess the enemies, traps, and walls around you and act very quickly. The enemies start out simple enough, with easy-to-tell movement patterns. However, subsequent zones become muh trickier, with things and foes that mess with your position or require you to be very attentive of your surroundings. Managing and understanding is key in reaching the end of the game.

There are a fair amount of extras here. In your regular runs you collect diamonds, which you use to unlock new items to find in your runs, upgrades like more life or a higher money multiplier, the opportunity to practice against bosses, and more. There are several different characters to play as, who all change the game in some manner, which can be as simple as requiring you to act in double time or as substantial as restricting your weaponry to bombs.

The music is fantastic. As you may expect from the title, it's all very dancable stuff. I seriously would listen to this at a party. Perhaps the best part is the various ways it's mixed when you enter certain areas. The graphics are in a pixel style and it looks and animates well enough.

In summary, Crypt of the NecroDancer takes rhythm and dungeon crawling elements together and brings out the best of both of them. Combine that with a great soundtrack, and the end result is a game that comes highly recommended.

Also, NecroDancer is a superb pun. I mean, it's simple and thematically appropriate!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Been playing roguelikes since... well Rogue and I'm always on the lookout for twists to the genre. By forcing the player to time their next move to the beat, the game not only adds a welcome challenge, but also gives a sense of immersion as everything on the board pulses with the click of the key. I almost felt as though I were orchestrating the entire dungeon's movements as I chose where to go next.

The game definitely captures the typical rhythm game's infusion of motion from the screen to the game controller to the player himself. I was tapping away with my foot and humming at times unawares as I got absorbed further into the game. And I'm only about an hour and two zones in at the moment.

Which is why calibration is extraordinarily important to this game. While you could manage by with a slight offset in rhythm, the game really benefits from having a tight link to the beat as you progress further and encounter harder enemies. This is especially so when fighting the various level bosses and when you fall into one trap, which teleports you to a special level, in which any mistiming of the beat automatically kills you.

Definitely an easy game to pick up immediately and start playing, but also full of challenges along the way to keep you going. Just make sure to calibrate well.

reviewText:
I am Going
To the Crypt
OF THE NECRODANCER!

I did not know what to expect. A Hardcore Rythm based Roguelike? So I watched the trailer and got hooked. Then I got it and I am absolutely amazed.

the basic priciple is like a turn based roguelike - when you move the enemies move according to their pattern. You crawl through randomly generated floors, try to find a boss monster, kill it and find the exit to the next floor. But what sets this apart is the rythm component. Because you can only move on a beat of the background music. And every beat makes the enemies move as well.

The Pixel art, albeit simple looks amazing. the Music gets you pumped and theres allways something new to discover.

the Gameplay and Action itself is tight. As in, you could take it slow, but if you so much as miss a beat, your multiplicator gets reset. Which means less gold and probably less equipment in turn, so you have to keep the rythm, move every beat and make quick decisions. And if the song runs out, the floor is over.

the music, Kick ♥♥♥. The way it should be for any rythm based game. But if you dont like it, you can use your own library to fill the floors with life.
the geme itself keeps you frustrated enough to make you wanna try again, because every enemy behaves in a certain way and you can train combat against them pretty early on - so if you die its because you got careless.

oh, and the shopkeepers voice is divine. Get the Soundtrach edition if you can.

10/10

[1.0 Update]

HO-LY-CRAP! I literally mean, Holy Crap! What they did with this is Divine.
I mean before the game was a 10/10 but now. Wow. just Wow.

new characters each with their own feel. Bard for easy Mode, other chars for extra challenges (like one that can lay infinite bombs and can kick them a few spaces ahead. Another one can only move in 2 space intervals.
The 3 main chars, Aria, Melody and Cadence now have little cutscenes after each Level, Bosses enter with an awesome Intro screen and announcement. the remastered Metal and Electro OST, that will play for Melody and aria are just Eargasmic.

If the Early access version was 10/10, this version is a 12/10.
I would love to give this two thumbs up, if possible

reviewText:
Now that the full release of this game has been out for awhile, I feel compelled to write a review of this game.

Crypt of the NecroDancer is a rogue like, rhythm based dungeon crawler that offers a unique challenge and experience, complete with multiple characters that have their own playing style that affects the gameplay greatly.

Pros:- Probably the most important aspect of a rhythm game is its music. Crypt does not disappoint in the slightest with its amazing tunes, composed by the one and only Danny Baranowsky as well as awesome remixes by FamilyJules7x and A_Rival.
- You can use your own music in the game, and this feature is implemented well.
- The game provides a hard but fair style of gameplay, something that is sure to keep people doing runs over and over again.
- Each of the characters adds an interesting twist (such as moving in cut time or being able to only use bombs) that provide an additional challenge for players to overcome.
- This game has high replayability as no two runs are exactly the same.
- A mix of items provides players with multiple ways to beatdown enemies to the beat.
- The devs constantly provide updates and work hard to fix any bugs that people encounter along the way.

Cons:- It can take awhile to get used to. You're probably not going to be able to get through Zone 1 on your first try. For some people, this may be a turnoff, though, if you're willing to put in the effort, you can really get a lot of enjoyment out of completing a run.
- If you're trying to 100% this game... think again. One of the achievements may be impossible to get, which may turn some people away.
- Pausing the game and regaining your pace can be rather difficult. While this may not sound like a big deal at first glance, there are some characters who will die if you miss a beat (Aria and Coda).

Some people may complain about the price, but you can find some 33% off coupons floating around on Steam. It's not much, but 10 bucks is less than 15.

TL;DR: If you like rogue likes, rhythm games, or dungeon crawlers, get this game. This game is an astounding combination of the three that works harmoniously. If the price seems like too much, go get a coupon from groups like Coupon Dumpster and that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Initially I had a really negative vibe from this game. I was frustrated because I found the rhythm aspect of the game overwhelmingly difficult, not because it is necessarily, but more likely it’s my lack of ability to time my movements right, and I found it hard to watch the in-game metronome while doing everything else. This is more of a personal problem though, and it doesn’t really reflect on the game.

However, I learned that there is another class called bard available from the start of the game. The bard can move freely without the concern of coordinating with the beat, and the monsters move when the player moves; more akin to a traditional roguelike. Playing bard has made the game enjoyable to me, and I look forward to possibly taking on the challenge of playing with the other characters later.

The game is well designed, and I’m impressed with the level it’s at for still being in development. The soundtrack is worth noting, it’s really good, and the pixel art is also very nostalgic, and in my opinion, it fits the game perfect. Everything you would expect from a roguelike is there too, but with a spin, and I respect the developers creativity coming up with something so unique. The play style may not be appealing to everyone, but the game will (and should) still be recognised as a good game.

Everything considered Crypt of the Necrodancer is a pretty cool game for alpha. I sincerely hope that development continues, and the game is finished. A successful pre-release all to often results in games being abandoned and pretty much just left in their current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the best games I've played in a long time. It's a mix of Spelunky and Binding of Isaac's zone and random item mechanics, all smushed in with a dungeon crawler and a rhythm game. It's fairly unforgiving but not deathly hard (unless you do hardcore mode or above, but that's expected).

It's definitely worth a play if you're a fan of rhythm games or dungeon crawlers regardless. The soundtrack is probably one of the most solid soundtracks I've heard on a game in quite a while, and even after 16 hours I'm still not tired of it and want to keep playing (though trying to resist due to waiting for missing content to be finished).

The game's in Early Access but you wouldn't notice it if it weren't for zone 4 being unfinished, so it's definitely in a fun playable state already and the only places it can go is up. There's a lot more content on it's way but there's no harm picking it up now, you'll definitely get your money's worth if you enjoy any of the genres within.

reviewText:
With 92 hours at the time of this review, I think its finally time I sat down and wrote a good review for this game. This review is going to be in a pro-con format so yah. Review Time!

Pros -The story is very well made and interesting, and a good motivator to keep trying to beat the first character (Cadence)
-Rhythm and Roguelike mashups that works perfectly
-Nice difficulty curve
-Lots of variety in runs and characters, so as to not feel repetitive (which it doesn't)
-Amazing soundtrack with now 4 different variants (2 of them you can only get through workshop mods)
-Every death is your fault, not the games
-The gameplay is spot on, with each weapon feeling really fun to play
-Local Co-op is very fun to play and is executed well
-Amazing community
-Practically infinite replayability with all the achievements and things to unlock
-Steam Achievements/Steam trading cards
-And so much more

Neutral -The game is very difficult to get the hang of, considering its very different from other roguelikes (this isn't a bad thing, it's just a thing I thought I'd point out
-Some of the characters are pretty difficult (Once again, not a bad thing, just something I thought I would point out.)

Cons -Part of the story is unlocked by Aria, who is a VERY difficult character to beat, or even get anywhere with (luckily youtube exists)
-Coda
-That's it really

Overall I give this game a 10/10. This game is honestly the best roguelike Ive ever played, with its awesome replayability, cool characters and a very interesting story, and its gameplay is spot on
Very much recommend!

Early Access Review

I can't get over how good the music is in this game. The gameplay itself is really simple, but incredibly difficult to get the hang of though. You need to constantly have a sense of rythmn to bop and tap along to. Once you understand what to do, its then time to worry about the endless items, chess games, conga lines, seemingly unkillable dragons, creepy- yet weirdly funky skellingtons, fake chests, fake walls, hot coals of death, combo-braking ice, rip-off shopkeeper, secret rooms, poisonous mushrooms and massive annoying trolls. Then theres the different playstyles of each character that you can play. Then there's the permadeath hardcore mode to try and master where you have to do all zones and conga-line bosses (God I hate the conga lines), or chessboard bosses in one run.

Overall a neat little game worth getting.

reviewText:
Steam is full of many indie greats. Brilliant, inventively crafted games that spring out of nowhere, and create gameplay formulas so well refined they earn themselves a place within the halls of all the greatest classic.

Whether its the addictive simplicity of One Finger Death Punch, the relaxing, almost zen like experience of playingE uro Truck simulator, or the stylish assassinating that makes Mark of the Ninja so great, there are countless titles on this services whose quality is very difficult dispute.

Crypt of the Necrodancer is one of those games.

The game hits you right from the get go with its gorgeously bright pixel art, which serve far more purpose than simply creating being a retro aesthetic.

The sharp, bright visuals bring the levels to life in a way that serves the gameplay perfectly, the vibrantly animated enemies movement (and dancing) to the beat in beautiful detailed fashion. The distinctively detailed enemy sprites don't just look great  - they serve to help you plan your attacks, always allowing you to quickly figure out what is going on, even when the hectic beat of the game's brilliant music threatens to eclipse your hand eye coordination.

The bosses especially are a treat, but I don't want to spoil those here. You'll just have to buy the game and discover what they are like for yourself!

Don't be at all surprise if you lose track of time playing this game. Progress is undeniably challenging but it has the one more go" feeling down to perfection. The more you play
date: the more you learn the important strategies needed to beat the dozens of different enemies you encounter
recommended: the best items to help you progress
hoursPlayed: and the endless number of secrets. Then you unlock a new character
voteText: and the cycle beings all over again.\n\nThere is nothing else like this game on the market

this is not the game for you.

This game deserves you attention.

reviewText:
I picked this up in early access, had a great time and set it aside to see how much better it could get.  Now I've got a rogue-light that's beautifully animated, brutally difficult with a boisterous soundtrack on my hands.  On top of that, Crypt of the Necrodancer has an array of laid back to nail-bitingly hard characters, all sorts of game modes (one of which makes the game easier for players that might want to use an actual dance pad to play, I gotta try that sometime) and even local cooperative play. I can't recommend this game enough.

real time action, dictated by the beat of music (except for one character, who causes moves freely)
well balanced; if you die and don't know why, you either learned something new or weren't paying attention
three soundtracks ready to mix'n'match
ability to import your own mp3s
steam workshop support, in-game level editor
10 unique characters
over a dozen weapon types with different tactical usages, which come in a variety of enchanted variants
loads of items that can have a drastic effect on how you handle situations
a fair host of enemies, each with movement patterns and special variants to keep you on your toes
7 bosses to discover and conquer, certain fights vary depending on your distance in-game
fully voiced cutscenes to tell the story of a number of the characters
wonderful sprite animation, everybody dances

reviewText:
A music game and a unforgiving dungeon crawler with heavy roguelike elements, all in one game. And it's not just a dungeon crawler with music game elements, or a music game with a dungeon crawl attached, it's a near seamless hybrid of both in a way that I never could have thought would work. But it does, so very well.

A soundtrack by Danny Baranowsky means it's going to be good, and the tunes go well with the rapid, split-second pace you need to keep in order to stay ahead of the game. I'm not sure if it's extremely difficult or I just plain suck, but I still have yet to get overly far in it and consistently blunder into enemies as I try to stay on time to the beat so as not to lose my combo. It's embarrassing, really. But my own suckitude aside, this is a game that's just so much fun, especially once you start getting into the zone and responding to things before your brain can really process them. It strangely reminds me of Hotline Miami in that sense, but with less ultraviolence and more dancing skeletons.

It is also now out of early access, and features a whole campaign, tons of unlockables and player characters with different playstyles, and daily challenges to keep you coming back. I must have rage quit this game a dozen times already but I keep wanting more, and it probably has something to do with those infectious beats. Nothing else is like it, and nothing else could do what it does as well as it does.

reviewText:
Crypt of the NecroDancer has ruined my life. I hear its catchy tunes in my head while I eat. I tap out the rhythm of dungeons in my car. And my children keep asking me what that funky song I'm humming all the time is. I can't stop thinking about this game, despite the fact it is deceptively hard and I may never actually get past Zone 3. So let me tell you why you should suffer the same fate.

In classic roguelike tradition, Crypt is an adventure through randomly-generated dungeons with randomly-generated loot to find and use on randomly-generated monsters. It's all laid out in a pleasing grid of pixel art, controlled solely with the arrow keys. Special items are used by pressing two directions at once, and attacks are as simple as pushing towards an enemy in range. Unlike other roguelikes, there's no random element to attacks. Everything has a set number of hearts, and if you hit it (or it hits you), you take the prescribed amount of damage. Monsters have set patterns to their attacks, meaning there are really no surprises to combat.

The catch here is that everything is set to the music, and you have to move on the beat. Enemies won't wait for your turn, either, because they're jamming to the same rhythm. Miss a beat and you effectively lose your turn. Suddenly this otherwise simple, predictable game becomes one of concentration and quick thinking. You need to be moving or attacking with every beat, and if you're focusing on keeping cadence, you're not focusing on strategy. Fortunately the game is desgined with this in mind, offering a robust tutorial, multiple practice modes, and even a second character unlocked from the start that can ignore the beat. There are four zones to conquer, each three levels and a boss. Beating the previous one unlocks the next, allowing you to skip ahead. You can also collect diamonds to purchase upgrades and new items to add to the random pool.

There's a terrible secret behind this welcoming facade, though. All of this is essentially an elaborate, extended tutorial for All Zones mode, which challenges you to beat all four zones in order, starting with the full item pool unlocked but no upgrades to your character. This is the proper roguelike mode for the game, and it is incredibly difficult to get through. Missed beats and damaging mistakes mount up fast enough to make beating individual zones a challenge, and starting essentially from scratch means your strategies have to be second nature. Unless the rhythm is in your blood, mastering Crypt is going to take a lot of time and a lot of practice.

Don't let that dissuade you from trying the game, of course. There's plenty to see and do even if you never touch All Zones mode. The many characters to unlock play like entirely different games, and you can access quite a few just by playing the individual zones. As expected from a rhythm-based game, the soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal and is sure to get permanently stuck in your head. Even if you keep getting mauled by mambo'ing skeletons, you're sure to come back for more. I really may never get past Zone 3 but I'm having too much fun to stop now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crypt of the Necrodancer is a game with admirable paicing, even allowing players to choose their own pace with differing characters and custom music. Whilst still W.I.P. I have not noticed a single bug so far, that or my sense of immersion to the actual game in terms of the music and the battling of monsters is just that great that I miss those bugs. Either way, the game is looking great, players new to this game will quickly get punished by the games relentless dedication to movement/rythm based fighting, often meaning that anyone who jumps in unprepared will end up dying a lot.

What does this say about the game? Maybe for the common, run of the mill gamer it might mean frustrating and unpreventable deaths. But to the dedicated gamer, those who use tutorials or at least have played a rythm game of some kind can grasp that everything requires key timing and a suprisingly large amount of strategy.

Do I reccomend this game? Yes. As of this moment its £10.99 ($17.94, €13.85), if you have the money, I fully reccomend buying and trying this game to anyone who is interested in it. More importantly I reccomend it as a backing to this genre of gaming as it is not often you see Rythm based games being produced. I know right now that more and more companies are making music based rythm games, but there needs to be a larger supply of them. With the people who made this game I do hope they make more like this as this genre is genrally underated, undersold and the variety of game titles is just too small.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You'd never have considered that rhythm games and dungeon crawling go together, but this game makes it work.

First off: this isn't a very serious dungeon crawler.  Most levels are small-ish and relatively uninteresting, with just a few rooms full of monsters linked together by various corridors.

What makes this work though is that the game is half real time, half turn based.  Based on the music playing for the level, each beat of the music is one turn, and enemies have a fairly mixed movement pattern based on the turns (e.g. one moves towards you every other turn, one moves in 4 directions each turn randomly, etc.).  This means that enemies move whether you move or not, but if you have the rhythm, you can anticipate where they will be and outsmart them.

On the easy levels, this is fairly straightforward.  As enemies progress and become more complicated, you also need to develop more complicated patterns, but what you will actually do depends on the minor variations in the level.  This means that unlike other rhythm games, you can't just memorize a button sequence for a particular song.  Instead, it is constantly changing.


The soundtrack is top notch, and design is pretty good.  There are plenty interesting enemies, weapons, accessories, spells, traps, etc. that make each replay sufficiently different to be fun.

Early Access note:  As of this writing, the game is In EA.  It has 3 zones (12 levels) and 5 characters ready to play, with a planned final zone and another 5 characters.  However, the current maps are plenty playable, plenty fun, and not buggy at all.

reviewText: A great combination of a roguelike and a rhythm game. It borrows elements from games like Speluny and Binding of Isaac - permanent item/character unlocks, a daily challenge, and of course random level generation and permadeath. The rhythm aspect makes it unique - unlike most rhythm games, you don't have to hit a particular button at a particular time, but there is a lot of strategy in getting the timing right to kill enemies and avoid damage - strategy which is enriched by the variety of enemy move/attack patterns and a number of items that affect your own movement and attack. It's all about planning ahead, and thinking fast so you don't lose the beat.

reviewText: A great combination of a roguelike and a rhythm game. It borrows elements from games like Speluny and Binding of Isaac - permanent item/character unlocks, a daily challenge, and of course random level generation and permadeath. The rhythm aspect makes it unique - unlike most rhythm games, you don't have to hit a particular button at a particular time, but there is a lot of strategy in getting the timing right to kill enemies and avoid damage - strategy which is enriched by the variety of enemy move/attack patterns and a number of items that affect your own movement and attack. It's all about planning ahead, and thinking fast so you don't lose the beat.

reviewText: I bought this game on sale and figured I'd get around to playing it eventually. Later that day, I sat down to play a different game, but decided to start Crypt of the NecroDancer up just to check it out.\nThe next thing I knew, two hours had passed and it was time to get ready to leave to go to my in-laws for Christmas. I grabbed my laptop and installed it real quick so I could play it while I was out of town (the system requirements are really low, so it ran just fine).\nIt might be one of the most addictive games I've ever played. I don't know how many times I've told myself, Just one more round
date:
only to spend another hour with it.
It's also very challenging in a Dark Souls kind of way. If you die, it's probably your fault. Instead of becoming frustrated, I only felt encouraged to try again and pay more attention to the movement patters of the enemies.
Also, the soundtrack is fantastic. So many of the songs get stuck in my head, which just makes me want to play it more.
It's my game of the year for 2015, hands down.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

YES.

I never knew how much I needed a blend of roguelike and rhythm but this is all I wanted and all I never knew I wanted.

Yes. This is exactly it. I love dungeoncrawlers. I love randomly-generated dungeoncrawlers. But there have always been something missing. Yes, the difficult combat, the constantly changing experience, making strategies against specialized enemies, those are all great, but there have always been something missing. Now I know what that is.

Good God, that is dancing. W-wouldn't Recettear have been even better if you had to dancefight? Dungeons of Dredmor? Chocobo's Dungeon? Nethack? Or the game that gave the genre its name, Rogue?

Yes. Yes it would. Don't fight me on this or by God I will dance you to the ground.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crypt of the NecroDancer is Incredible
I got this game expecting to have a few hours of fun and then get bored. 20 hours of play time later, this is still not the case.
This game is almost therapeutic to me. I have a lot of anxiety issues, and this game is such a great way to get my mind off of things. Just go with the flow and listen to some great music by Danny Baranowsky.
Also, the customizability in this game is great. I do a lot of sprite work, so I've already sprited one of my original characters into the game. You can add your own music as well, but I have not explored this feature yet, so I cannot vouch for it.
This game is also a great way to get some fun exercise if you have a dance pad. I bought a dance pad just to use it with this game.
Even though this game is still in Alpha, I cannot recommend Crypt of the NecroDancer enough. The art style is great, the music is by Danny B so it's amazing by default, and it is fun to play. Get this game. Throw your money at this game. If you like rougelike games and have a good sense of rhythm, you will not regret your purchase.

reviewText:
tl;dr -> Played this game, now I can't help but bob my head and bounce on my feet whenever I'm walking and hear an EDM beat. 11/10 disco dungeon dance-off simulator.

NOTE: You can read my full review here[theroguereviews.com]

I was fortunate enough to receive this as my first-ever review copy (yay!). Very, very excited to try this game because I adore the rogue-like genre and enjoy beatmatching when I mix my electronic dance music (EDM) at home. Crypt hit on many of the themes and concepts that I’ve always loved, and I thoroughly enjoyed my gameplay experience. This is easily one of the best staples available in the rogue-like genre.

If you like rogue-likes, rhythm mechanics, dungeon crawling, electronic music (Danny Baranowsky’s score), and constantly unlocking new things, then you will really love this game.

The aesthetics are great – the amount of detail in the different levels and characters is well-done. The retro, pixel graphics combine with the electronic musical score to provide a very fun, fast-paced experience reminiscent of old-school arcade games (including the high difficulty that usually accompanied them). Danny Baranowsky’s music is critical to the gameplay – since you have to time your movements with the beat – and fits well with the heavy rogue-like elements found in the game. If you are partial to electronic music, then you will enjoy the great soundtrack. If you don’t, however, like EDM and/or Danny’s style, then you can always use your own music (MP3 format). There is a unique track for each level, and you have the option of loading your own playlist for each level. Note, I have a very wide taste in music, so I tried an assortment of genres – EDM tracks work very well with the rhythm mechanics (because of the consistent beats per minute), but Ariana Grande (I love her) songs DO NOT work very well. That being said, Danny’s composition is fantastic, and I don’t mind replaying levels over and over again, listening to the same tracks every time. Another advantage of using EDM tracks in a custom playlist is the length – the levels end in line with the track playing, so EDM’s lengthier (on average) playtime gives you more opportunity to explore the floor. The story involves you falling into a dungeon, your heart being magically tied to an ominous beat that you must dance to.

The controls are fairly easy to learn – a tutorial is offered that teaches you the basics of gameplay. I personally prefer using a controller over the keyboard, and I suggest you use that instead. The learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with rogue-likes and/or rhythm games. Before you start playing, you will have to do a latency test for visual (the heartbeats and beat prompts) and auditory (the actual beat) cues; you can redo the test whenever you want. There is an “easy” mode that you can play, however, I sincerely think you will find a fair challenge playing the regular difficulty. Also, if you want a break from the beatmatching, you can play as a character (Bard) who does not have to move in time with the beat.

Difficulty is something this game does very well, especially for a rogue-like. Characters you unlock will usually have harder playing conditions (ex: cannot kill enemies, die when you pick up gold), ramping up the challenge factor. To combat this, you can unlock a character/room that allows you to practice against the different enemies you may encounter – this allows you to recognize their movement/attack patterns and how to best deal with them. A character/room also exists that allows you to train against mini- and regular bosses. I highly recommend you at least check these out once you have them available, especially if you are having difficulty progressing through the levels. There is even a room that provides levels where you can learn advanced tactics, like how to kill the shopkeeper in different ways. I appreciate this approach to difficulty because it provides you with the tools to improve your playstyle, should you so choose.

Gameplay involves you moving around a grid-based dungeon floor, most times in synchrony with the beat (unless you are playing as the Bard). Monsters on the floor also move in time with the beat, and they attack based on a chess/checkers-style pattern – if you move onto a tile that a monster was about to move to, you will take damage. Also, if you move into the attack range (varies based on the monster) of a monster, you will take damage if it is ready to attack – they usually have an animation cue (ex: skeletons raise their arms) to let you know an attack is incoming. To take advantage of monster movements (all units have to move each beat, or “turn.”), you can do things like backtrack or hit a wall (which will keep you on the same tile). As you progress through the level, monsters will drop gold. To increase the amount of gold dropped, you will have to build up your gold multiplier by hitting all track beats (when you move/attack) within a small window. Every time you miss a beat or take damage, your multiplier will decrease by an increment. Picking up armor will decrease how much damage you take, but will not affect your multiplier. Gold is used to purchase items from the large variety of stores available. Multipliers are especially effective when paired with multiplier-based equipment (ex: damage dealt is based on your current multiplier).

Overall, the game is an immense amount of fun and always a fair, interesting challenge.

If you are any bit interested in the rogue-like series or rhythm gameplay, then I implore you to give this game a try. It definitely is one of the best rogue-like titles available today.

ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND!

Cheers,
DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

My Website[theroguereviews.com]

reviewText: Picked up on sale.  Another rogue-like game to enjoy.  The idea of movement based on the beat makes this game require some quick thinking.  This, like most rogue-likes the random drop can make or break players like me.  I found myself replaying levels all the time and hoping for certain drops.  Once you unlock some of the characters it allows you a little more freedom to play.  I took the bard out to solve all levels to get an idea of what I was getting into before I started to attempt with the main character.  Fun game for sure and pretty cool when you start to add your own songs into each of the levels.  Worth the pickup, but dont expect to be spending 100+ hours unless you have an extensive music library.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unexpectedly Brilliant!
I had been browsing Steam for at least an hour, looking for something that might hold my interest for more than a few minutes. By the time this game turned up, I was not very hopeful. The gloomy title conjured up images of a tedious slog through yet another Tolkein knock-off world. The screenshots reminded me of a hundred junk titles that bill themselves as retro" and "8-bit" to lure long-time gamers into parting with their money in a quest to recapture good memories from their childhood. The description
date: touting the unlikely fusion of roguelike and rhythm genres
recommended:
left me almost certain that this was nothing more than a concept gimmick that would fail to meet even the lowest of expectations.

I could not have been more wrong.

Crypt of the NecroDancer is the most inspired
hoursPlayed: refreshing contribution to gaming that I have encountered in years. This game blends the simplest and most predictable mechanics with enough variety to be challenging and so much creativity that even casual players will have a whole lot of goofy fun. reviewText:
Last time I wrote a review for this game it was in it's early access, alpha 0.44 stage, and now, after it's full release, the game just keeps getting better and better.

Every time I stop playing I can hear the catchy music playing in my head, especially Melody's (one of the main protagonists) themes.  This music is pure gold, no matter which track I listen to.

The levels are procedurally generated, and so are the enemies that go along with them, making game play change each time you load up and play.

The large assortment of items and upgrades you can purchase in the game's lobby (for diamonds you find on each level run) is large and diverse, with many different rings, weapons, spells, health upgrades, etc. at your disposal.

The player and enemy movement design is flawless, and whenever you start battling you begin this dance of death" with whatever you're fighting. And when you die

reviewText:
My first serious review.  This game has changed my opinion so much from the first time I played it I wanted to write this incase I can convince at least one other person who may have had similiar feelings as me when I first played it.

I tried playing this game a few times as Cadence when I first got it.
It was somewhat fun, although not enough to keep my attention.

Then I tried playing as the Bard.

It was fun not having to worry about the beat of music, and instead just learning enemy movement and attack patterns.
When you play as the Bard the whole game becomes turn-based.  Each move you make causes the enemies to do one movement.
A solid rogue-like.  You basically play over and over until you get familiar with all the enemies, each time you feel yourself getting better and better at this game.

I was in zone 2.  Just doing another run, when it hit me.  Even as the Bard I found myself moving to the beat of the music.  I was using my shovel to dig through dirt which added its own sound to the music playing.  I was realizing that some of the movements I was making when fighting a particular enemy was almost like doing dance moves.

It hit me.  This game is freaking genius.  Playing through a few times as the Bard is almost a necessity and I wish the game developers would have somehow made it more obvious that this should be a first step.

Binding of Isaac used to be my favorite Rogue-Like, now I can say without a doubt this is my new favorite.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have a soft spot for a well executed genre mashup, and Crypt of the NecroDancer hits the bullseye of that sweet spot.

It's a smart, slick roguelike where a run takes little more than 10 minutes to play, but is engaging from the start. The inclusion of a rhythm-action mechanic, where you're rewarded for moving on the beat of the music is both novel and fun. It adds a sense of urgency (and sometimes panic), while also opening up a risk/reward mechanic of when it's smart to *not* move, lose your multiplier, but gain a tactical advantage in your approach to a given enemy.

The enemy and powerup design is varied and interesting, allowing each run to play out very differently. There's  a very strong feeling of ongoing progressive mastery that happens, as you figure out the right way to defeat new monster types and the best way to utilize the items you pick up.

Of particular note is that you can brush the dust off your old DDR dance pad, and use that to play the game. Any game that allows you use old ludicrous peripherals scores bonus points in my book. Now, who wants to play a couple of rounds of Streetfighter with a Dreamcast fishing rod controller? FIGHT!

Note - while it's still notionally in Early Access at the time that this review is written, it very much feels like a finished game with free content coming down the pike.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

And it's like, how much more niche can you get?  The answer is none.  None more niche.

Seriously though, this is a pretty fun roguelike.  It gives me the same vibe as One Way Heroics, even though their gameplay is fundamentally opposed: They both add an element of tension that isn't present in normal roguelikes.  In the case of Crypt of the NecroDancer it's a very frantic tension, which makes it hard to play for long stretches at a time but I'm really enjoying it when I do play.  Ideal coffee break game, each run is nice and short.

Replayability is similar to Spelunky: It's very challenging as you play through it, but I'm not sure how much I will feel like replaying it once I'm finally through.  Various things to unlock along the way though.  Playing with the different weapon types is a lot of fun, it feels more visceral than most roguelikes and that's very satisfying.

The music is addictive.  There's a mode that lets you play it with a dance pad, too, and I'm really looking forwards to that--will update this review when my new dance pads (with official Crypt of the NecroDancer art from precisiondancepads.com!) arrive in a month.

Early Access Review

I've had interest in this game ever since I heard of it, and it has been worth following the creation of this game. This game in my opinion is just amazing in every single way, the enemies, the equipment available, the gameplay, and on and on. The main thing to me which defines this game is its amazing music, made by Danny Baranowski (who also created The Binding of Isaac music, and when I learned of this I was very happy).

This game is still in early access, and has amazing potential and in the current state of this game, it is overall just amazing and fun to play. Even if you are not the kind of person who has interest in music based games, you should still keep up with this game and its development as the potential is huge. If you dislike the music for whatever reason, there will eventually be music you can use yourself to play the game with!

Also a dancepad will be usable for this game.

TLDR: Buy it. If you choose not to, keep up with the development of this game, and eventually you will like it.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Holy hell this is addicting!

Now if you want a new AudioSurf... this is not it. The custom music is a little difficult to delve into, and while it does work, it seems to have a little trouble with tempo changes; you may want to stick to fairly consistent (and definitely pulsing, driving) songs if you use it. Bear in mind that at the time of this review, this is in alpha, and they may well improve the beat recognition.

That critique aside, this game is wonderful so far. It offers loads of charm, and actually does a shockingly good job of merging roguelike and rhythm games in a way that makes it feel very much like a quick-paced puzzle game. I highly recommend it to fans of any of those game types and look forward to continued updates!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWith only three hours in this game, it's already my third favorite indie game of all time (behind Bastion and To the Moon). An extremely difficult permadeath game, Crypt Of The Necrodancer is one of the few difficult games I have that manages to be difficult, but not ragequit material. Every death feels fair- you died because you have something else to learn about that enemy, or you weren't prepared enough. It's rather frustrating for a little after you're thrown into a new zone to relearn different strategies for the new monsters, but the moment you manage to finally figure out what to do it's a wave of power unlike anything. And then you die to another monster and try again- but you don't care because now you're one step closer. The music is fantastic (though the shopkeeper's voice is slightly annoying) and moving to it becomes very simple because of how well written the music is. I haven't tried with custom music yet, but I'm looking forward to it and continuing to play the game.

Early Access Review

Crypt of the necro dancer is quite a different game. It's a blend of rhythm, fighting and rogue like with the idea of moving and attacking to the beat. The only problem i've had so far is the learning curve is quite steep to the third zone, but other than the curve the game seems pretty good! The developers of this game are extremely responsive to the community asking for ideas, reporting bugs, and trouble shooting with errors and crashes. I fully recomend this game!

TL:DR I entirely recommend this game! The game is an amazing blend of rogue like and rhthym with beautiful visuals and music! I rate 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I preordered this game ages ago to get early access to the alpha build, and the sound track.  I could not be happier with my purchase.

Clever game play combined with wonderful pixel graphics, and a soundtrack that will seep into your subconcious mind combine into an engrossing gaming experience that will challenge even the most experienced dungeon crawlers. I normally don't endorse early access games, but this one is an exception that all others should strives to model themselves after.  The first build of this game was light years ahead of what many games on Steam now call final builds, and for that I am eternally grateful.  New additions to the game are seamlessly added on a regular basis, and any bug or issue are often taken care of quickly and effectively.   I cannot stress enough the professionalism Brace  Yourself Games have shown with this release, both with the handling of this game and in their forum community.

I cannot recommend this game enough.

If you like roguelikes. Go for it.
If you like rhythym games. Go for it.

If you're like me and somehow fall in that strange Venn Diagram overlap then What the hell are you waiting for.

reviewText:
~~UPDATED FOR FULL RELEASE~~

Rhythm-based Rogue-Like Dungeon Crawler. Yes. Please.

Everything you do is to the beat of the music, you move to the beat, attack to the beat and die to the beat. And the enemies do too. Every enemies has an attack pattern so if you can feel the beat, you can avoid taking damage, but it's not always that easy when you have a limited amount to time to react (IE. the beat) The music is the first thing you'll notice, composed by the indie game music GOD Danny B. who did the soundtracks for Binding of Isaac and Super Meat Boy (He's done many other games as well, but those two are the other two that I've played and can personally vouch for the music) so you know that the music in Necrodancer is top-notch...which is good considering that's the prime game mechanic.

You'll groove your way through 4 zones, beating monsters, collecting gold, buying items and beating bosses until you reach the final boss which is sometimes different if you play the different characters. All the different characters are truly different and all play very differently and some even have limitations as to what items they can get. All the different characters ensure that you never get bored with the game and always provide a new challenge if you're feeling up for it. Played too much Cadance lately? Switch it up with Melody. Don't like how Melody plays? Try out Eli. Feeling strong with Eli? Now try Dorian. There are 10 different characters to play, including one final, truly insane challenge character that literally nobody has beaten yet so there is always something new to aim for with this game. And even if you can't play some of the harder characters like Aria, Bolt or Monk, you can always lay beatdowns to the beat with all the other characters.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crypt of the NecroDancer is exactly what it is described as: a rogue-like rhythm game.
This game is all about patterns. Each type of enemy moves to the beat in a specific way, and you need to learn these patterns to effectively defeat them.
The simplistic controls are what really drive this game home. You only use four buttons to perform all of the moves in the game - up, down, left, and right, to be precise. The game's control scheme is so simple, in fact, that you can play it with a USB-enabled dance pad, like the kind used for DDR-esque games. Personally I have not tried this, though I definitely want to!
Even though this game is in alpha, it is still jam-packed with features to entertain you for hours of playtime. I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm having great fun with this game.  More than that, I'm fully loving it!

It's a unique and wonderful idea to combine a rhythm dancing game with true rogue-like gameplay.  The game has a great range of pickups, gameplay options, different playable characters, etc.  It just feels so well made.

Necrodancer has a brilliant soundtrack by Danny Baronowsky, who also did the music for Super Meat Boy.  I'll buy any game with his name on it, no questions asked!  (and the soundtrack too)

They've made the game cross-platform for Linux / Mac / Windows.  I do 99% of my gaming on Linux and I really appreciate the Linux support.

You can play with keyboard or a controller, or real dance pads.  I've ordered a pair of dance pads to play it the hard way.  I might even get fit.  There's a two-player co-op option, so I can play with my wife or kids and use both the pads.  The game is challenging enough with plenty of variety to keep me playing while I lose some weight necrodancing like a fool!

Although this is an early access game, it already has more options and features than most full release" games:  training halls to practice battling different monsters and bosses (if you can pay the entry fee!)
date: a huge variety of pickups and upgrades
hoursPlayed: local co-op
voteText: daily challenge...  I don't recall another game with so many great options.  The procedural generation gives a great variety of levels
helpfulPercent: on a par with Spelunky.\n\nIn short
votesHelpful: buy this game already!"

votesFunny: true
column16: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The ingenious combo of a dungeon crawler and rhythm game.
GAMEPLAY

It's a dungeon crawler rhythm game. Your movements are timed to the beat of the song, and you can't just spam movements all the time. It's simple, but is executed so well and so satisfyingly that it's become my favorite dungeon crawler (which isn't saying much as i've only played 2 at the time of this review and only have 9 hours in the other one) Since everything is timed to the beat, you're retreating with the beat. You're killing to the beat. You're flanking to the beat. You are living with the beat. This makes the game incredibly satisfying to play.

Enemies play by their own rules also on the beat, which becomes incredibly complicated in the later zones where the screen gets cluttered frequently, with enemies that play by their own rules, or the same rules on different beats. Enemies can in later zones also potentially move diagonally, something you can't do, and even through walls, which never felt fair when you die to those things.

There are different character types, all of whom have different styles of play. Some may be incredibly satisfying and fun, others will leave you begging for mercy and crying face down on your keyboard. A very good replay value.

SOUNDTRACK

Kick ♥♥♥. You get 3 different soundtracks

DannyB-The creator of the game's original soundtrack
A_Rival-The creator of the game's EDM soundtrack
FamilyJules7X-The creator of the game's metal soundtrack.
As well as custom .mp3 support, which is incredibly satisfying and adds even more replay value. Problem is, the beat detection can be a little off for songs with a large amount going on or different pacings (I'm looking at you, PAYDAY 2 songs)

OTHER

Mod support, as well as a very simple to modify game.

CONCLUSION

I was never a really big fan of dungeon crawlers. I always felt that, while they each did their own thing, they were pretty much the same thing in general and gameplay-wise. Crypt of the necrodancer is not pretty much the same thing in general and gameplay-wise." It's a game that takes roots from rhythm games and dungeon crawler games to create it's own thing which is a very satisfying and fun to play game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EPIC game. I've always been a fan of the Rogue-like gameplay like Dungoens of dreadmore or Rogue Legacy, but this one takes the price.

The one thing i never liked too much about the rogue-like is that if you wanted to play it perfect you had to take tons of time to analyse each move. I always had the feeling that is was the game that killed me, not just because i played bad

Crypt of the NecroDancer have fixed that. Whenever i die i feel like i'm an idiot for not realizing that it was a bad move, but because of the time limit-aspect you make mistakes. You just have to hope you don't make mistakes when it really matters!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is the best rhythm game I have ever played. The game is not finished but it is still really good. If you like games where you kill monsters in classic pixel lands, then you should play this. Be wary of a steep learning curve though, it takes time to get used to moving to the rhythm and slaying beasts. While you can change the music on this game I have yet to do so. The music is good enough to listen to for hours on end. The music is made by Danny Baranowsky the creator of many amazing game sound tracks such as Super Meat Boy. There is also a hardcore mode where you get no upgrades and have to start from the ground up each death. You can also do this as a daily challenge to see how you stack up to other players traversing the same dungeon layout as you.
