reviewText:
I LOVE this game. Take NetHack, add cute pixel graphics and a charming story, make the turns happen to the beat of music, and compress the whole experience down to a bite size morsel you can consume in 30 minutes - and you have this little gem. I bought the game for $7US, and then promptly bought the soundtrack for $15US which is the only music I’ve listened to for the past 5 weeks.

This game starts off hard, and then gets brutally hard as you unlock the more advanced characters. But I’ve never felt the game cheated me, despite dozens of deaths. Each one was my fault, and mine alone. I wasn’t fast enough, I zigged when I should have zagged, I didn’t prioritise the right enemy, I didn’t control a boss’s movement. There is an element of RNGesus, but your skill and experience is the biggest factor in your success, or failure, by far.

Did I mention I love this game?

reviewText:
Since its alpha phase, Crypt of the NecroDancer has held a ton of promise.  As it's grown into its full release, Crypt has added multiple characters, an expansive monster bestiary, and not one, but two extra arrangements of the already-amazing soundtrack.

This game is a rhythm-based roguelike dungeon-crawling game, but rather than carefully planning each move, you're given a time limit of a single beat of music.  Everything moves one turn on each beat, whether or not you offer an input, which means that you're constantly faced with split-second decisions which will make or break your run through each zone.

Crypt offers a wide variety of play styles.  Cadence, the first playable character, is a pretty standard roguelike experience.  You take on a dungeon, probably die, and return to the lobby for some purchasable persistent upgrades.  You return to the dungeon, and the cycle continues on.  Later, you'll unlock Bard, a character whose actions are not limited by the beat of the music, and enemies only move on player actions.  And for the perfectionist, Aria offers a frustrating challenge in which missing a single beat or taking any damage is instant death.

The soundtrack, which I mentioned earlier, is absolutely amazing.  Danny Baranowski (of Super Meat Boy and Binding of Isaac fame) takes center stage with the primary soundtrack.  Two other musicians -- A_Rival and FamilyJules7x -- also offer their talents to mix the game's music into heavy techno and metal arrangements, respectively.  Each of these remixed soundtracks is available to play in the game as well.  And, if you should ever get bored of that music, the game allows you to use your own music for any stage you please.

I could go on for paragraphs about how great this game is, but suffice to say, it is absolutely worth experiencing for yourself.  It's well-made, it's challenging, and above all else it's just a really fun time.  Absolutely pick this game up if you have any interest in rhythm-based gameplay, roguelike dungeon-crawlers, or just generally challenging gameplay.

reviewText:
Crypt of the NecroDancer
A little pixel Game I saw on a friends PC. I was a bit suspicious about that, but now I really like it.


GamePlay: You control a little man/woman, depending on who you play. The only keys you have to press are ↑ , ↓ , → , ←.
Sounds simple and not very exciting, but the most interesting part is, that you have to press them in the right rythm.^^
Listen to the music in the background may helps.
This is still not all. Every Enemy in the game also moves in this rythm and they have some patterns.
(e.g Blue Slime: Moves one block up, skips a beat and then moves one block down.)
This is one of the simplest patterns. Others have patterns with no set directions and they'll try to get you.
Additional to that enemies may have some special attacks. (e. g Red Dragon: when you are in the same horizontal line the dragon will spit fire that deals damage to the entire horizontal line.)
Items also exist which helps you to fight against enemies.
Not to forget, other characters, other kinds of this gameplay. ;)
Sometimes it's very challanging, even with the Bard"

reviewText:
Rhythm-based roguelike that has you move to the beat to kill and avoid monsters. Deceptively hard and good music. I was going to beat it to completion, but then Overwatch and The Witcher 3: Blood and Wine expansion came out. So take this recommendation for what it's worth: deserving of your time if you don't have the money or a good enough computer for other, better games. That's a back-handed compliment, but I'm not really a huge roguelike fan. That I played this long enough that I could no longer refund it is compliment enough.

Four out of five Lennys

reviewText:
As an off-and-on fan of rogue-lite/like games, I am always torn determining the amount of skill and the amount of luck you will find in these games. Unseen probabilities within games are something I always am wary of complaining about when I could've had some really bad luck.

However, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a game where I blamed myself more so when I made errors than blame the odds against me. This is the first rogue-LIKE where I could tell I was improving myself, and it's the first one in the genre where the demands on the player's skill were mandatory.

Because with each failure through the familiarity of the controls and the coodrination of my fingers to the bass-line of the music I was reading the enemy telegraphed moves. Or adjusting myself to a new tempo-change. Or finding myself becoming at ease with the bizarre control-scheme. (Minus the DDR pad.)

The Rogue-Like With A Beat
The novelty of this game is that it takes the game of Rogue and gives it a beat. Literally.

The musical theme is not solely an aesthetic. The gameplay is interwoven into the music itself. From the way you move around/attack to the amount of time you have to explore the dungeons. Once the song ends, you are dropped to the next stage. (There are red-bars to show that the song is nearing its end.)

Every movement/action you make is managed by moving in-time of the music. You and every enemy move according to that rule, which gives the game a charming tactical feel while sometimes relying on you thinking on the fly. Enemies attack in a specific manner which usually results in them having an off-beat" to strike them. If you simply attack head-on with no regard
date: you'll die a lot.\n\nIf that sounds too convulted about how the combat works
recommended: let me rephrase it like this: You are the metronome; the music is what you need to match (as the tempo can increase and decrease); and the enemies are the other instruments in play. The game plays more like reading a music sheet than another rogue-like game.\n\nThe controls are the first major obstacle to get over
hoursPlayed: which you can play this game legitimately with either a controller or keyboard (or a DDR pad
voteText: which has an easier difficulty just for itself). To get the best experience
helpfulPercent: I would suggest you map your directional keys separate from your combo keys. There are too many moments towards Zone 2 and onwards that rely on twichy relfexes in-time with the music to coordinate your fingers in combinations.\n\nThankfully
votesHelpful: the game isn't too demanding on you maintaining a constant rhythm. If you're like me
votesTotal: I struggle to keep a rhythm going longer than a few seconds without going faster or slower than expected. The game is leniant on being perfect
votesFunny: but you cannot spam your movements. The game simply won't let you
commentsCount: and you won't be able to obtain the modifiers to your gold (and modified items) if you don't keep the beat.\n\nI was able to get past the first zone on my KB alone
column16: but the second stage's music tripped me up when I had to make those split-second motions to drop a bomb or use an item. Switching out the combos to other keys fixed it for me
column17:
and I would strongly suggest that if you play the game with a controller you get the directional pad some love.

Practice Makes Perfection
Many rogue-lites rely too much on probabilites of which you can and cannot control (FTL). Others rely on attention to details of your item and the levels to spot those small benefits to get you to the end (Binding of Isaac). Crypt of the NecroDancer is a part of the trend where they provide permanent progression across chunks of the game.

(There is a story mode for purists who want to play a more traditional rogue-like experience. However
column18:
I chose the permanent item/stat increases as I am not the best at these type of games.)

There are stat increases and new loot to give your next playthrough something to change it up as well as possibly improving your odds. None of which are mandatory--I wouldn't think of going without them--if you are good enough at the game to read your enemies' movements.

Outside of the item/stat increases
column19: you also have another means to improve your next game: Practice rooms.\n\nYou have a training room for enemies and minibosses that unlocks with a certain amount of kills for every enemy
column20: a boss pratice room (unlocked via currency you accumulate in every run
column21: diamonds)
column22: and a weapon-training selection screen to practice in either room. These rooms are unlocked by finding trapped tradders within Zone 1 and 2 and unlocking them with the Golden Master Key.\n\nHaving a story-mode option and a perma-progression system as choices is the best compromise as both the purists who prefer to learn the game on their own and everyone else has the means to finish the game. But it ain't so easy
column23: nor free.\n\nThe bosses cost in-game currency to unlock. And you can't simply practice on all the enemies from the get-go--you have to kill each enemy type several times to unlock them. Simply
column24: you can't cheat yourself out of a challenge without investing first.\n\n(And if you don't like some items
column25:
you can discard them for diamonds with the Janitor).

It Ain't No Stepmania
Perhaps the game's own lacking feature is the infamous difficulty of its genre. The game doesn't feel that hard.

Make no mistake; the game is difficult for all the right reasons
column26: and you will die a lot. But there are plenty of items to circumnavigate the game's difficulty
column27: and some enemies that make me wonder how fair the game truly is.\n\nFor example
column28: blood items let you regain your health
column30: with enough kills chained together. There are also magic spells that might stun enemies
column32: or give you some buffs to become overpowered in some situations. I would chalk these up to limitations of making a novel game without all its polish.\n\nSome enemies also break the rules. There are some enemies that move in diagonal movements
column33: which you are never allowed to do. The red-dragons also seem unfair without a "ranged" weapon (weapons that extend beyond one-tile
column34:
such as long-swords or broad-swords) to get around taking damage.

Zone 2 seems to have a sharp difficulty spike because you start off with nothing (even if you finish Zone 1). So expect that you may still have some bad runs when you begin new zones.

The only feature of this game I hadn't tried is adding your music into the game. This game's music was tailored for the game
column35:
and I am sure slow songs will break it while Megalovania will result in a very bad time.

Shake Your Groove Thang
This is one of few rogue-likes I'll always come back to because it's a fun experience. It's not a brutal old-schooling
column36:
nor is it coddling to the new players. The game's sense of challenge makes an otherwirse creative deviation into a worthwhile game of its own.

And how can you not have fun dancing on a plastic pad like an idiot?

(Kudos to the devs who put this through Early Access and finished the game. As well as for adding new content to the game itself with no DLCs. If they have another product through Early Access
column37: be sure to give them a second glance.)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow.  Just... Wow.  Where do I begin?  A buddy of mine got me this for X-mas and I've been playing it non stop.

Great Retro Pixel Artwork.  Interesting and addicting game mechanics.  Plus a soundtrack that makes you hit restart just to listen to it again.

Danny Baranowsky does again, and writes rockin', catchy tunes that'll be stuck in your head for days.

The game is still in Beta, but that doesn't stop it from being fun one bit.  I can't wait for updates from the developers, because I'm always left with wanting more of this awesome experience!  But don't worry, the game gets updated often.

Challenging, Addicting, and just plain adorable, Crypt of the Necrodancer gets a 10/10 from me!

Excelent work! The Rhythm part isn't so precise as in Rhythm tengoku or similar games, but it does arise the need of thinking quickly, which makes it far better. With a total of 10 characters to play as, the game has a natural learning curve, which gets of the charts at the end!

Either way, I heartly recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of rogue-like or disco-esque music.

reviewText:
There have been many music-based games in recent years. I remember buying Audiosurf in 2008 and thought that it was so unique getting a game that plays on highway-like track according to the song you play. Many rhythm-based games have been distributed over the years and Crypt of the Necrodancer is one of them. This game is different because it looks like it is set in a randomly generated dungeon with a roguelike character strictly moving to the beat of the music.

You start the game as Cadence, a female character you control to collect gear, coins, and spells while a variety of monsters try to stop you. It has a very steep learning curve and it takes a while to get used to moving correctly to the beat despite the fact that the monsters have very predictable moves as they try to reach and attack you. If you move to the beat correctly, you will build up a coin multiplier while the maze turns into a disco like settings since it looks like a brightened dance floor. If you miss a beat, the coin multiplier will be lost and you will have to build it back up again. Each zone is divided into a few levels and the final level will be a boss level. Defeat the boss at the end of the zone and you will unlock a new character. There are many characters to unlock and each has such different moves that if feels like you have to unlearn the moves you used with the previous character. There is a character named Eli who can drop an infinite number of bombs and kick them to defeat nearby enemies. This means that you will have to get accustomed to the different attacks that Eli features that Cadence does not feature. Cadence moves to the beat and kills with conventional weapons like swords and whips. Another character, Bard, doesn’t have to move according to the beat whereas another character like Dove cannot kill enemies, but can exit the levels without facing mini-bosses.

Besides the diverse characters in terms of number and abilities, the levels include a challenge in which you can rescue NPCs trapped in a cage that require exploration to find the proper key to liberate them. These NPCs will then become available in the lobby so that they can sell gear, spells, and other goodies that will be useful in each zone and its associated levels.

The number of diverse characters, the complexity of the movements can provide plenty of replay value. Also, you can play your own mp3s to see how challenging each level in a zone can be. When playing a song from the game’s soundtrack, it is funny to see the shopkeeper sing along to the music. The music that comes with the game is varied and entertaining. The game includes daily challenges and workshop mods to add up to infinite replay value.

I think Crypt of the Necrodancer is a game that was well thought out by the developers, combining coolness, diversity, and difficulty. I think people can enjoy the challenges and the diversity of the characters and dungeons/mazes that this game offers. It is unique to combine the traditional roguelike characteristics of the game with rhythm. Just be prepared to put a lot of practice into the game that requires fast thinking since one mistake can easily force you to start over. Beating a level will always feel very rewarding due to the need for precise hand-eye coordination.

My Score: 8/10

reviewText:
This game fooled me, but in a good way. I was expecting a cute gimmick - a music game disguised as a rogue-like. Instead, I got a solid dungeon crawler with a musical twist.

Crypt of the Necrodancer is the first game to combine two of my favorite things; EDM and The Undead. The style is cute, cohesive and somehow works without jumping the shark, which is hard to do for such an odd mix.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow, what an amazing game!
I love its style, the music and the whole gameplay.
When I first bought the game I played it for 5 hours straight, without getting tired of it.
It is just so much fun to play.
But it's not just a rhythm game, you have to think about every single move, which means you have to think fast and react even faster. You have to predict the moves of your enemies, but at the same time focus on the beat and your moves.
At first it is pretty hard, but after some time you'll get into it and you'll love it!
This is one of the few early access games I'd recommend, because even now it's ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutely amazing. The music will enter your head and refuse to leave, but for once, that's a good thing.
The controls are extremely simple to learn, but deviously tricky to master. Even though it can get extremely hard, there's also easier modes and built-in systems for practicing against that enemy that you can't seem to get past, or even if you just wanna relax and explore a bit. To add on top of how beautiful the game is and entrancing the music can be, there is plenty of room for customization through the Workshop, or even just your own music! There is so much to say about this game, so many things to explore, and it's not even entirely done yet! If you like rhythm games, rougelikes, or even just games that have plenty to explore, get this game!

reviewText:
It's like a spiritual successor to The Binding of Isaac and it's probably the best indie game I ever played. It's very fun to play and because of procedurally generated levels this game has amazing replayability even after you played it for many many hours!

I can't think anything bad about this game, I guess, at first it would feel like a very hard game, but just after a few hours you'll be much better at it, just keep practising and you'll be fine.

The OST deserves a special mention also, this is the Danny Baranowsky at its best! And if you liked Super Meat Boy or The Binding of Isaac OSTs, then you'll be in love with this game!

I rate it 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When it comes to Early Access games, it can be hit or miss, most are bare bones and can be left unfinished, but others can be real gems that show the quality and talent indie games are known for, this is one of them, a game that already feels complete and plays very well, but hats off to the developers who wish to improve this game more to the best that it can be.

High Points:  The controls are tight and responsive. The level design is always different, and yet the levels overall are kept rather short and rather straightforward, which is a big plus for these kinds of games. The variety of items and unlockables to get help encourage you to continue playing over and over again. The music, no doubt the highlight of the game, the music is addicting, enjoyable and will get stuck in your head for hours.

Critique: As it stands at the moment, the game is pretty solid, but there is always room for improvment.

1. More variety in items - If there is one thing Binding of Isaac has shown, is that with a large variety of items that all work differently, it helps make every playthrough different, with different items everytime, so it'd be nice to have something new other then rings, boots and such.

2. Floor gimmicks - It'd be interesting if on all floors of other then the boss floor, there was a chance of a gimmick happening that can change the whole experience, like being chased by an invincible enemy, having no map to use, line of sight restricted, or even having a larger level the normal.

3. More traps - I think some more traps might be needed to spice up the gameplay, like spin tiles to mess up the controls, moving traps that follow a set path, and perhaps traps that trigger if you move into their line of sight.

Overall: I feel overall this game is looking really good, and I know when it finally comes out, it'll be a big hit.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love games that make sense of old gaming tropes and conventions; in this case, how about the old idea that enemies in roguelikes only move when you do? The answer is, they're just moving to a beat, same as you!

This idea has serious gameplay implications as well. Roguelikes were always about positioning and strategy, but let you take as much time as you wanted in between turns. The rhythm nature of this game melds it into an action game with the best of tile turn-based. Fighting enemies is an absolute joy: every time you walk into a room you have to think fast, what enemy do I prioritize and how do I position myself to attack them while keeping myself out of harm from other enemies.

There are a few mechanics that really help facilitate this; for one, the control scheme is exclusively arrow keys or WASD, which means that attacking is done by pressing in the direction of an enemy, overriding a movement in that direction. This can play to your advantage or disadvantage depending on your weapon and circumstance, which just increases the layers of things to think about. It also means you can play the game on a dance pad if you want to, with no compromises. The one downside is that using subitems like consumables and spells is done by pressing combinations of those direction keys, which doesn't really feel great and you'll often forget which thing is bound to which button combo. It can screw you up in a frantic moment.

The other element really strengthens the rhythm game connection: a multiplier. If you can keep landing enemy kills without straying off beat, you'll earn a coin multiplier, which is cool because coins serves as both currency and as points or high score. What makes it interesting is you lose the multiplier for using a wait command essentially, which means you have to constantly keep moving. This not only changes the tone of the game, but it makes approaching enemies interesting too, as you'll have to find another way to stay in the same spot without losing the multiplier.

Then you have different items and weapon types, and what's great is that even though the very basic attack up" weapons will change how you fight enemies
date: there are a lot of different types that change properties and completely change how you approach combat.\n\nAnother big mechanic is that each floor is timed
recommended: and you'll be sent to the next when time runs out. This is probably an improvement over other roguelikes that give you as much time as you want; at the same time
hoursPlayed: it along with the multiplier makes the game feel really frantic. While it's a cool feeling you don't really have the chance to learn what an enemy's all about in the middle of a run
voteText: you'll have to utilize the in-game beastmaster mode to learn enemy strategies. Same goes with items

column18: it just takes awhile.\n\nThe game has a really smart progression system early on; basically it splits each of the zones of a full length run into its own adventure
column19: and gives you incentives to play and learn them with the diamond system which gives you permanent upgrades to your character

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is what you get when you blend together a SNES-era RPG, chess, and DDR. Who'd knew it's be so entrancing?

Do notice (again) that it's still a work in progress. Not enough unlockables, the game still runs on a excuse plot (trailer says about Cadence's missing dad, opening just sets her on finding out how she survived a cracked skull. You won't hear about either anywhere else in the game), and even though using your own MP3 is an seducing idea, the beat-detection program, Essentia, is hit-and-miss on some musics, even with the double and half tempo options.

Give it time for the team to work it out though, and enjoy what has been released so far. It's addictive :3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great music, and the ability to import your own songs makes it where you're unlikely to get bored of the sounds.  While each enemy tends to be pretty easy to take down, a horde is a challenge, and can be overwhelming at first.  Thankfully, for those of us who are always off-beat or are overwhelmed, an alternate character (the Bard) allows the game to act more like a traditional rogue-like (with fantastic music), where the enemies take their turn after your character moves.

Give the awesome variety of items, shrines, and teleporters already in the game, I'm really looking forward to see what they add during the remainder of development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love Rogue-like games, but have always disliked the concept of rhythm games. Oh man have I had a lot of fun with this. The soundtrack is awesome, and the gameplay is well thought out. When you die, or lose life you only have yourself to blame, no cheap tricks. And the learning curve only highlights how well made this game is.

That being said, there is obviously missing content, as it is in Early Access. The amount of levels is alright, but the overall content seems a bit lacking. It's easy to run out of things to look forward to after you've beaten the 2nd zone (out of 4) as the hub feels rather empty.

I'm hoping they don't pull a CuttleFish and cut all forward content after early access release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You like rhythm games, yes? Do you like the undead? No? Well that might end up being a bummer for you friend, because this game has it in SPADES. If you like fast beats, ingenious game mechanics, and incredible replayability, then look no further! Crypt of the NecroDancer has everything you're looking for.

Feel your pulse pound to the beat, hijacking your limbs; meet your new master.

Introduce yourself to the denizens of these dungeons, dance along with them... and kill them!

And when you think you've had enough, you haven't, for through all this, you now know...

The Crypt of the NecroDancer has you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crypt of the NecroDancer is a fantastic entry into the Roguelike genre, so let's break it down.

The primary draw of the game is the great music and how it is worked into the mechanics. In order to succeed you must move and attack to the beat of the song assigned for the floor. This is both simple and wickedly difficult to keep up, but the better you manage the more gold coins you earn due to a multiplier effect.

Stats in most roguelikes depend heavily on luck in finding items or leveling up, but in CotND you can definitely succeed with just the basic starter gear. The reason why is because the game doesn't rely on huge health pools and in fact most monsters can be killed in a single hit and the only monster you MUST kill is the boss on the final floor. Playing conservatively is a very viable tactic because there are many ways to advance to the next floor and there is no leveling up that requires killing monsters.

Each dungeon, at least for the moment, is three dane-a-thons of fun and a final boss. So game sessions are short and failure does not leave that typical bitter taste.

There's a light quirky sense of humor, especially when the shopkeeper starts belting out tunes with the music. Colors are bright and all the monsters get a little dance-y jig which makes things pretty playful. If you're doing well you also get magical disco lighting all over the dungeon, huzzah!

This is the Roguelike for people who like music and a shorter, more meaningful play session. The game itself isn't super long, but the random elements and multiple character types will keep you as busy as you would like.

Final Score: A-

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When it comes to Early Access games, it can be hit or miss, most are bare bones and can be left unfinished, but others can be real gems that show the quality and talent indie games are known for, this is one of them, a game that already feels complete and plays very well, but hats off to the developers who wish to improve this game more to the best that it can be.

High Points:  The controls are tight and responsive. The level design is always different, and yet the levels overall are kept rather short and rather straightforward, which is a big plus for these kinds of games. The variety of items and unlockables to get help encourage you to continue playing over and over again. The music, no doubt the highlight of the game, the music is addicting, enjoyable and will get stuck in your head for hours.

Critique: As it stands at the moment, the game is pretty solid, but there is always room for improvment.

1. More variety in items - If there is one thing Binding of Isaac has shown, is that with a large variety of items that all work differently, it helps make every playthrough different, with different items everytime, so it'd be nice to have something new other then rings, boots and such.

2. Floor gimmicks - It'd be interesting if on all floors of other then the boss floor, there was a chance of a gimmick happening that can change the whole experience, like being chased by an invincible enemy, having no map to use, line of sight restricted, or even having a larger level the normal.

3. More traps - I think some more traps might be needed to spice up the gameplay, like spin tiles to mess up the controls, moving traps that follow a set path, and perhaps traps that trigger if you move into their line of sight.

Overall: I feel overall this game is looking really good, and I know when it finally comes out, it'll be a big hit.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An absolutely fantastic combination of roguelike dungeoneering and rhythm game. That darn Necromancer has your heart and is forcing you to move to the beat. Of course, you can skip the beat, but we really suggest you don't. Every enemy has its pattern, every item has its individual use and every run is sure to be completely different and enjoyable.

Devs are very active and frequently adding new things, you can put your own custom music in and it's fairly good at recognising the beat (I highly recommend Hotline Miami's soundtrack). Several characters to pick from, a few more when you beat the 'hardcore' mode (a straight run through all the levels, a feat I've yet to accomplish at time of writing). Every death will have been avoidable and will leave you asking yourself why you did that, rather than blaming the game or enemies.

A very satisfying game to play, could not recommend it any more strongly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

15 bucks might seem a bit steep for what looks like a simple pixel-art roguelike game, but trust me when I say this: BUY IT.  This a truly unique game, and although the mash-up between genres (roguelike and rhythm game) may seem strange at first glance, it works brilliantly here.  Danny Baranowsky killed it with his score - I find myself humming the songs in my head when I'm at work.  Gradually learning the different strategies for dealing with the various enemy types is extremely rewarding, as you'll eventually work your way up from dying every time you run into your first miniboss to being able to complete runs in 'hardcore' mode, where the real fun is.  Add in daily challenge runs, multiple unlockable characters that dramatically change elements of the gameplay, and more content to come, and you'll be getting way more than your money's worth.

Easily the best game I've picked up in a long time.  A+, 100%, 5/5 etc.  And it's only in alpha!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll admit, I was a bit skeptical of this game when I first started.  I loved DDR and I love roguelikes, but to mix the two?  What fresh madness was this?  THIS WAS THE EPIC MUSIC MADNESS OF THE DEEP!  The music is energetic and fun, the game is easy to learn and the tutorial is short (seriously, VERY short, but all you need to know).

The game is most certainly a roguelike, no saves, randomized layouts and drops.  But that's just the beginning.  Your ability to sync your movements to the beat isn't just a gimmick.  This mechanic rewards you with things like coin bonuses for the long combos you can create as you dance through the levels.  It requires you to plan while you move, if you stop, you miss a beat and you lose your combo.

The game is simple and addicting.  You never feel too bad about dying because you use the rewards you gained from the previous play to help you on your next, simply perpetuating your endless jimmy through the dark tunnels as you slay monsters with  your dance moves and your beat only legend can recount.

A bit pricey at $15.  I bought it on sale and it was well worth the money.  If you love roguelikes and love awesome soundtracks, it could very well be worth the money.  If you're on the fence, wait for a sale and jump on the deal like Jon Travolta on a disco beat.

No wait; it's both. It's a procedurally-generated labyrinth in which your actions come in pace with the music. recommended: and promising to only get better as time goes on.\n\nYou play as Cadence
hoursPlayed: a novice gravedigger (I think; it's not really important) who makes one shovel cut in the wrong place too many. Now your still-beating heart has been stolen. Turns out this isn't as fatal as you'd expect
voteText: and it even means you can't die permanently
helpfulPercent: but it HAS made you a Slave to the Rythm(TM). Can you make it through the NecroDancer's lair in order to kill him and reclaim your heart? Or will you be a slave to the rythm for all eternity?\n\nEverything in the NecroDancer's crypts moves and acts to the beat of the music. You can use your own MP3s for this
votesHelpful: but the included soundtrack from Danny Baranowsky is so awesome you won't need to. Mastering the beat of the music is the key to victory in this game.\n\nRemember when I said Crypt rocks the "easy to learn
votesTotal: hard to master" hat like a boss? This is why. Moving with the beat is one of those things which is very easy to wrap your head around
votesFunny: but mastering the beat is a whole other story. It's a simple concept executed flawlessly
commentsCount: made all the more satisfying by the fact that it makes you angry in the exact right way - with yourself. Harm comes because YOU screwed up. Failure becomes because YOU screwed up. At no point does the game throw anything at you that you can't deal with - or at least
column16: can't learn to deal with it. We can all name dozens of games that are plain broken
column17: where often failure comes because either the game did a whoopsie in its pants or because the random number generator decided it hates your face. Crypt doesn't do that. There's only one thing Crypt will get you angry with; yourself. And that makes it so very compelling. When you fail
column18: you want to do better. You want to get back in there and get further - to wipe away the shame of your earlier failure. Before you know it
column19: you're hooked.\n\nSpeaking of which... I need to find a new vein so I can get another hit of this delicious juju."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crypt of the NecroDancer is a rhythm roguelike dungeon crawler. What to say. This game is 100% fantastic. A great challenge while also being incredibly fun. Moving on the beat and hitting monsters along with the flow of the music is an incredibly satisfying feeling, especially on enemies like dragons, following the pattern of hit-move-hit-move until they're dead. Every enemy design is great in its own way, as well as every character sprite. Cadence's animations are flat-out adorable.
The music, integral as it is to the gameplay, is incredible, and easy to listen to over and over again. Which is kind of common, in a game as difficult as NecroDancer. My only problem with the game is very, VERY minor. It's about the beat bars at the bottom of the screen, near the image of the beating heart. They kept throwing me off the beat ever so slightly. Thankfully, the devs put in the ability to turn off the beat bars. Thank you.

Verdict: 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't always dance, but when I do, It's because I smashed my head on a rock, and a Necrodancer has stolen my heart from my body, pretty much dooming me to live an eternal unlife as a back up dancer for MJ's Thriller or as an extra on Soul Train.

Or so I was able to surmise from the very brief intro cartoon.

Frankly it's a stupid concept, especially when strapped to something as random and difficult as a rogue-like, and deserves ridicule---

---Except that this game somehow brings me more actual joy to play than maybe any other game ever!

Seriously, pure joy, displayed on my face as I play, a smile I think they call it. I hit the keys to the beat, stretching the limits of my rythmless suburbanite white guy imagination to picture myself laying out a boogie-woogie beatdown in the only way I know how (the sprinkler, the electric slide, the macarena).

When I fumble the beat (losing my gold bonus AND my flashing checker dance floor effect) or die to what I'm pretty sure was a zombie elvis, I frown just as hard as I was smiling moments before. But no! It's not over yet Zombie Elvis. This is a rogue-like, baby, so I know I'll be seeing your randomly generated gyrations again real soon. Assuming I dont die to a golem that likes to shimmy and shake it first.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best music around, coupled with the best music integration since Audiosurf, wrapped nicely into a roguelike dungeon crawler with plenty of depth.
My biggest complaint is that there aren't any extra songs past the default for each level. You can have the game play any song you load, but the ingame music is so perfect that I wish they made more to choose from.

RECOMMENDED for people who like dungeon crawlers or rhythm games.
ESPECIALLY RECOMMENDED for people who like both.
LESS RECOMMENDED for people who dislike permadeath. Everything can be countered, but you'll die a lot of times figuring out how.

reviewText:
No joke, this was one of my favourite games of 2014.

In theory, this is a really simple game.  Grid-based roguelikes have been done before.  The real seller of Crypt, however, is the impact of the game being set to music and moving rhythmically.

Unlike a lot of similar games, Crypt forces you to learn and memorize patterns and react fast and skillfully, instead of spending forever mulling through cluttered inventories for the exact item to get you out of your situation.  It's about speed, snap decisions, and learning, and above all is completely fair - everything in the game could be handled flawlessly with just your starting equipment.

There's a lot of other aspects that are strengths to it.  Mechanically, the game reaches an incredible level of play diversity, not just from the vastly different playable characters.  It also comes from the fact the massive pool of items are rarely just a straight upgrade over one another, and instead have different strengths, weaknesses, and benefits.  Presentation wise the game's super slick, charmingly animated, and the music is bloody amazing too.

Do the thing.  Get the game.  It's amazing.

reviewText:
This is one of the only Early Access games that I have purchased very early on. It also happens to be the first early access that I have absolutely loved from the beginning and it's probably one of the only early access games that I purchased that actually came out as a complete game.

Crypt of the Necrodancer immediately caught my eye because of its unique gameplay (or was it just an impulse buy because of the pun?). It's essentially a Rythm Roguelike game. It has most of the elements of a Rogue-like, except you have to stay on beat!

The soundtrack is absolutely amazing (and now offered in 3 different variations!) and the game is deceivingly difficult. It's very easy to pick up, very hard to master and highly addictive.

Even having played through the first 3 zones countless time while I waited for the fourth one to come out, then all four a bunch of times when it did, I still enjoy playing this game from time to time (I have played a lot more than Steam indicates.)

I often despise randomly generated levels but in this game it works very well and follow a set of logical rules. Each level will always be similar while always offering something new. There are tons of different items that will help you on your runs and different characters that provide different challenges when you get bored of Cadence, the main character.

A very charming and challenging game with a lot of replayability, fully worth the 16.99$.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is hands down one of the best examples of why Early Access should be a thing. Amongst the piles of early access games that are slow to update, have uncommunicative developers, and don't strives for self-improvement, Crypt of the NecroDancer continues to add more content and build upon itself.

And it is ALREADY worth its price.

A clever blend of rhythm game and rogue-like, Crypt of the Necrodancer is a fun challenge that urges your every move to be carefully thought out and chosen...in the length of a beat. The music is incredibly catchy, the bosses and characters are charming, the design is delightfully elegant, and the different playstyles made available always keep things fresh. And there's still more characters, zones, and content to come!

I've yet to try out the importing of custom music, nor have I used the custom level editor to its fullest potential. But I honestly can't say I'm missing out; I'm still addicted to the game's levels as they are!

Do yourself a favor. Buy it. Support the developers. And bide your time until you can confront the NecroDancer in a lethal tango.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very fun game, 100% worth buying even at full price. (And as a notorious cheapskate, that's not something I say lightly.) Don't be discouraged by the early access tag; this game is very well polished already, and recieves regular updates. Even if they never updated it again, it would still be worth buying. You will have a blast playing this single player, and if you have someone to play with the local co-op is great as well.

Pros:
Refreshing concept, executed wonderfully
Nice tight gameplay
GREAT soundtrack
Lovely pixel graphics and animations
Good amount of content/replayability
Steam workshop

Cons:
Custom song importing doesn't work as well as you'd hope (beats are off/weird sometimes, but maybe I'm picking the wrong kind of songs)
Very unforgiving of mistakes (but it's a roguelike so that's to be expected)
You have to be good at memorization (Hey, it's a con for some people)

I'm sure there were other things I wanted to mention so I'll probably edit this review at some point. But all-in-all very nice game, quickly becoming one of my favorites. Definitely recommend.

THIS GAME IS SO GOD DAMN GOOD!!!\nBut now for a real review of the game on something that really stood out to me while playing, and that was the difficulty of it. On of the most popular games I could compare the diffiulty to is Dark Souls  (trust me its nothing close to as frustrating). You see one of the things I loved about the difficult in Dark Souls is that it wasnt you aimlessly attacking and just beating the game, you had to be constatly thinking and reacting to everything you and your oppenent were doing. In CotND you need to know the enemies pattern, the rythem of the current song, and your postioning relative to the enemies arround you. If you mess up on a single one of these while in battle you will most likely not come out of a battle healthy. The difficulty is based only upon how much you have planned ahead for the situation. However, you will most liely need to give every level a fair amount of tries to get the patterns of all the enemies down. reviewText: Necrodancer is an enjoyable mashup of rhythm based and rouge-lite elements that end up working surprisingly well together. The game suffers from the same problems that most indie rogue-lites do and that is that it becomes fairly repetitive after a few hours of play due to a general lack of enemy variety. Still, the game does have 10 playable characters, each with their own gimmick to help diversify time spent playing the game. The game also comes with 3 soundtracks as well as the ability to use your own mp3s so that you don't have to listen to the same soundtrack over and over if you are having trouble getting past a particular zone. It's the kind of game I pick up and play a little of everyday and overtime has really grown on me.

reviewText: Crypt of the Necrodancer is an amazing take on the Dungeon Crawler genre while also putting in a spice of rhythm making the game enjoyable and better to listen to. Every rhythm game needs a decent soundtrack to succeed. Not only did Danny B. (Also known for his music in BoI and Super Meat Boy) fill this quota but Rival (known for his Electro Dubstep type music) and FamilyJules (Creator of several Metal Covers on OSTs.) made this game's soundtrack amazing. Not only that, but the characters are rememberable and make you actually feel for them, giving you different gameplay for each character, which is where Crypt of the Necrodancer gets it's replayability. These are the reasons why I still come back every day to this game. The art looks fresh and actually makes you wanna stop and see how your character moves to the beat of the music. This game also supports Steam Workshop, giving you the ability to play as a jiggling piece of bread if you wanted to. All of this for the decent price of $14.99 makes me believe that ANYONE, whether you enjoy Roguelike Dungeon Crawlers or the Music Lover that listens to game soundtracks in their daily lives can enjoy Crypt of the Necrodancer.

reviewText: This game includes more differences than other rhythm games and differences are mostly positive. Firstly, you don't have to move with continuously flowing display like that audiosurf, beat hazard, guitar hero etc. so you can choice your own destiny. In short this is the first platform music game. Secondly, this game have useful workshop that allows creating mode easily althought there is no tools belong to game. reviewText:
Easily one of the best rhythm games to come out EVER. CoTND is a procedurally generated dungeon crawler with the difficulty and addictiveness of Binding of Isaac, with, imo, a killer soundtrack. This is probably because the music was made by the same guy but, I digress.

And if for some reason you hate the music (or you get sick of dying and hearing the same bloody song from level 1 over and over again like I do (inb4 'git good')) you can substitute the level songs with your own music.

You play at Cadence, one of several musically-named individuals who must make their way through the titular Crypt for their each individual reasons, which is fun but the true awesomeness lies in the music-related combat and sweet pixel art visuals. That being said the game is hard. It's really hard. The good news is with a few proper upgrades you can become veritably unstoppable in any of the worlds. The learning curve drops into a cliff about the time you meet the Red Dragon, who can take you out with a single well-timed fire breath from across the map, and he'll show up every now and again in Zone 1.

Easy to learn and hard to master are how I would describe this game, and would definitely recommend it unless you're known to break things if you get easily frustrated. Mice and keyboards are expensive.

reviewText:
This is one of the only Early Access games that I have purchased very early on. It also happens to be the first early access that I have absolutely loved from the beginning and it's probably one of the only early access games that I purchased that actually came out as a complete game.

Crypt of the Necrodancer immediately caught my eye because of its unique gameplay (or was it just an impulse buy because of the pun?). It's essentially a Rythm Roguelike game. It has most of the elements of a Rogue-like, except you have to stay on beat!

The soundtrack is absolutely amazing (and now offered in 3 different variations!) and the game is deceivingly difficult. It's very easy to pick up, very hard to master and highly addictive.

Even having played through the first 3 zones countless time while I waited for the fourth one to come out, then all four a bunch of times when it did, I still enjoy playing this game from time to time (I have played a lot more than Steam indicates.)

I often despise randomly generated levels but in this game it works very well and follow a set of logical rules. Each level will always be similar while always offering something new. There are tons of different items that will help you on your runs and different characters that provide different challenges when you get bored of Cadence, the main character.

A very charming and challenging game with a lot of replayability, fully worth the 16.99$.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is hands down one of the best examples of why Early Access should be a thing. Amongst the piles of early access games that are slow to update, have uncommunicative developers, and don't strives for self-improvement, Crypt of the NecroDancer continues to add more content and build upon itself.

And it is ALREADY worth its price.

A clever blend of rhythm game and rogue-like, Crypt of the Necrodancer is a fun challenge that urges your every move to be carefully thought out and chosen...in the length of a beat. The music is incredibly catchy, the bosses and characters are charming, the design is delightfully elegant, and the different playstyles made available always keep things fresh. And there's still more characters, zones, and content to come!

I've yet to try out the importing of custom music, nor have I used the custom level editor to its fullest potential. But I honestly can't say I'm missing out; I'm still addicted to the game's levels as they are!

Do yourself a favor. Buy it. Support the developers. And bide your time until you can confront the NecroDancer in a lethal tango.

reviewText: Necrodancer is an enjoyable mashup of rhythm based and rouge-lite elements that end up working surprisingly well together. The game suffers from the same problems that most indie rogue-lites do and that is that it becomes fairly repetitive after a few hours of play due to a general lack of enemy variety. Still, the game does have 10 playable characters, each with their own gimmick to help diversify time spent playing the game. The game also comes with 3 soundtracks as well as the ability to use your own mp3s so that you don't have to listen to the same soundtrack over and over if you are having trouble getting past a particular zone. It's the kind of game I pick up and play a little of everyday and overtime has really grown on me.

reviewText: This is easily the game of the year for me. It looks pretty innocent and silly, but it's extremely addicting and quite difficult. It's like the perfect mix of Guitar Hero and your favourite roguelike/dungeon RPG. Your mission is to build a character with powerful items and bring him/her through multiple terrifying zones and well-designed bossfights. All of this without breaks, because you'll be moving to the beat of the (honestly beautiful and catchy) soundtrack. So you'd best learn every enemy and every item in order to maximize your chances of survival, and even then it's hard. Not only that, but there are more characters to choose from which provide different (read: insane) challenges.\n\nI know 15 bucks is quite a lot for an indie game these days, but definitely buy it, it'll be so worth it. It's also one of the most unique games you'll ever play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't always dance, but when I do, It's because I smashed my head on a rock, and a Necrodancer has stolen my heart from my body, pretty much dooming me to live an eternal unlife as a back up dancer for MJ's Thriller or as an extra on Soul Train.

Or so I was able to surmise from the very brief intro cartoon.

Frankly it's a stupid concept, especially when strapped to something as random and difficult as a rogue-like, and deserves ridicule---

---Except that this game somehow brings me more actual joy to play than maybe any other game ever!

Seriously, pure joy, displayed on my face as I play, a smile I think they call it. I hit the keys to the beat, stretching the limits of my rythmless suburbanite white guy imagination to picture myself laying out a boogie-woogie beatdown in the only way I know how (the sprinkler, the electric slide, the macarena).

When I fumble the beat (losing my gold bonus AND my flashing checker dance floor effect) or die to what I'm pretty sure was a zombie elvis, I frown just as hard as I was smiling moments before. But no! It's not over yet Zombie Elvis. This is a rogue-like, baby, so I know I'll be seeing your randomly generated gyrations again real soon. Assuming I dont die to a golem that likes to shimmy and shake it first.

I am bad at this game, but I love it, and the music is phenomenal and fun, and the ability to customize the music makes it even better. Next time I throwdown with dancing fantasy creatues I'm gonna queue up that These Boots were made for walkin'" song so they know I mean business

reviewText: I have been interested in Crypt of the NecroDancer for a long while then. All my friends who I have asked about it who have played the game say its really great. Now that I have tried the game I say I agree. NecroDancer is two parts rougelike one part dungeon crawler with a sprinkle of beat matching game sprinkled in. Every action throughout Necrodancer is done to the beat of each levels song. You try to move down floors through the dungeons while collecting loot, fighting monsters and just generally trying not to die to some sort of nasty trap.\n\nI feel like Crypt of the NecroDancer is a well rounded challenging game and I recommend it to any rougelike fans.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very fun game, 100% worth buying even at full price. (And as a notorious cheapskate, that's not something I say lightly.) Don't be discouraged by the early access tag; this game is very well polished already, and recieves regular updates. Even if they never updated it again, it would still be worth buying. You will have a blast playing this single player, and if you have someone to play with the local co-op is great as well.

Pros:
Refreshing concept, executed wonderfully
Nice tight gameplay
GREAT soundtrack
Lovely pixel graphics and animations
Good amount of content/replayability
Steam workshop

Cons:
Custom song importing doesn't work as well as you'd hope (beats are off/weird sometimes, but maybe I'm picking the wrong kind of songs)
Very unforgiving of mistakes (but it's a roguelike so that's to be expected)
You have to be good at memorization (Hey, it's a con for some people)

I'm sure there were other things I wanted to mention so I'll probably edit this review at some point. But all-in-all very nice game, quickly becoming one of my favorites. Definitely recommend.

reviewText: If you haven't already read this enough in the other reviews I'll say it again.... THIS GAME IS SO GOD DAMN GOOD!!!\nBut now for a real review of the game on something that really stood out to me while playing, and that was the difficulty of it. On of the most popular games I could compare the diffiulty to is Dark Souls  (trust me its nothing close to as frustrating). You see one of the things I loved about the difficult in Dark Souls is that it wasnt you aimlessly attacking and just beating the game, you had to be constatly thinking and reacting to everything you and your oppenent were doing. In CotND you need to know the enemies pattern, the rythem of the current song, and your postioning relative to the enemies arround you. If you mess up on a single one of these while in battle you will most likely not come out of a battle healthy. The difficulty is based only upon how much you have planned ahead for the situation. However, you will most liely need to give every level a fair amount of tries to get the patterns of all the enemies down. There is never a moment when I would think oh that's stupid of the game" it was always "oh I was stupid it do that." You will need to learn and them plan you attack to all of the enemies in each stages. Heck and just like Dark Souls this even applies to after you have gotten far past the first level. For example

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rating: 9/10
Quote I would use: It's like Pokemon Mystery Dungeon with a Rythmic Twist!

Such a new idea for a game!
The game is like a dungeon crawler with a twist, you move to the beat.
When I first heard of this idea, I thought it would be a silly gimick with nothing to it.
But when I started playing to the Amazing soundtrack (same guy who did the Supermeatboy soundtrack),
I was having alot of fun with it, killing enemies with my sword to the amazing and quick beat (theres a little timeline for you to follow the beat to). I haven't played too much of the story but It gave me a nice cheesy epic vibe.
I was surpised to be able to use my own songs to play to the game (this is so awesome and appreciated.
The Dungeons re-generate making every experience challenging and unique. The enemies are killed in a way I haven't seen before which is cool! This game is also super awesome to play with a buddy.
The game is easy to learn but hard to master (you will die alot at first).
Absolutely recommended.

reviewText: Crypt of the Necrodancer is an amazing take on the Dungeon Crawler genre while also putting in a spice of rhythm making the game enjoyable and better to listen to. Every rhythm game needs a decent soundtrack to succeed. Not only did Danny B. (Also known for his music in BoI and Super Meat Boy) fill this quota but Rival (known for his Electro Dubstep type music) and FamilyJules (Creator of several Metal Covers on OSTs.) made this game's soundtrack amazing. Not only that, but the characters are rememberable and make you actually feel for them, giving you different gameplay for each character, which is where Crypt of the Necrodancer gets it's replayability. These are the reasons why I still come back every day to this game. The art looks fresh and actually makes you wanna stop and see how your character moves to the beat of the music. This game also supports Steam Workshop, giving you the ability to play as a jiggling piece of bread if you wanted to. All of this for the decent price of $14.99 makes me believe that ANYONE, whether you enjoy Roguelike Dungeon Crawlers or the Music Lover that listens to game soundtracks in their daily lives can enjoy Crypt of the Necrodancer.

reviewText:
Crypt of the Necrodancer is definitely one of the most unique roguelike games I’ve ever played, with the added bonus of actually resembling rogue instead of using roguelike as another term for “permadeath without saves”.  You play a family of musicians (or a motley crew of side-characters) determined to unlock the mystery of the magical lute and defeat the Necrodancer, a cursed necromantic bard.

True to its name, you “dance” around each level by moving in tune to the rhythm meter at the bottom of the screen. Each level has its own tune and rhythm and the game steadily increases the pace as you progress. Keeping in tune with the music while vanquishing enemies will net you a higher multiplier which increases the amount of gold you find, in addition to enhancing certain special items found throughout the crypt. Failing to keep to the beat will cause your multiplier to go down and may also prevent you from moving. Since the monsters in the game also move to the beat, they will eventually close in on you to attack and you cannot stand still to “pause” the action (unless you’re playing the bard character).

I found the soundtrack for CotN to be excellent and very diverse. Each level’s song fits its theme pretty well and there are a few tracks that are instantly catchy. The shopkeeper in each level will also sing along with the music, giving a clue to his location, and all of the monsters are either music-themed or have a name alluding to some musical term or instrument, adding an extra layer of detail to this thoroughly polished game.

There really aren’t any faults with this game that would prevent any fan of rogues from picking it up (playing as Aria is extremely hard though) and, even if you’re not normally into games in this genre, the learning curve is very fair. This game is worth picking up even at its original cost, though if you can catch it at the average sale price of $5 it’s quite a steal!

reviewText:
Warning to all who dare to enter the Crypt - If you have no internal metronome, turn back now. Seriously, you need to be able to hold a beat to even consider playing this game in full. And yes, this is an important distinction - I've seen several attempted runs from someone who didn't, they were very short lived. Another warning - If you have any music preferences, they're about to be formatted.

Anyways, Crypt of the Necrodancer is a roguelike rhythm game. The roguelike takes precedence for the most part, but it's good to keep a rhythm-game mentality. The gameplay can be a bit tricky at first, but superb once you get the hang of it. The actual progression is a bit basic (not uncommon for roguelikes), but that's not too major a problem. The biggest issue most people have with the game is that the rhythm-based controls are a bit gimmicky or unwieldy, but I had very little problems with them and they didn't get in my way too much.

But enough about the gameplay. I'm writing this review to commend the SOUNDTRACK. This game's BGM alone is worth the $15 admission fee, and that's a bargain. I've been known to listen to the soundtrack on repeat for hours on end, and am working on burning the soundtrack onto a CD as I type this. And if the planets align and someone is born who doesn't like the music - you can set your own too.

So in summary: If you think you can manage the gameplay, get the full game. If you don't think you can manage it, already have the game, or need a new soundtrack to listen to in your spare time, buy the soundtrack. And if by some strange coincidence you neither want this game's gameplay nor it's soundtrack, then and ONLY then will I permit you to not touch this game.

What are you waiting for... pick up the beat!

reviewText:
Having just completed all three main storylines, I feel I can safely recommend this game now.

I haven't played a lot of roguelikes in the past, but I can safely say I will be pursuing them in the future, largely due to the incredible enjoyment I had playing Crypt of the Necrodancer. It's a very well designed game with unbelievably good music and tons of replayability. Even after beating the main story I still feel like I'm only scratching the surface.

Since this is my first review I won't go into the minor pros and cons of this game, but I will give it a 9/10 and recommend to anyone even remotely interested. Glorious.

reviewText:
Quite fun. The mechanic of moving to the beat is an interesting gimmick, although I can't seem to get the hang of it. Keep missing some beats (because the soundtrack is incredibly excellent? Heh... not really. Just great, but not superb kinda thing). The soundtrack changes every level you go on, meaning that the beats change pace level to level. This also provides a nice variety while playing - you move at a different beat every level, and combined with the randomly generated levels (can't memorise paths - they always change) provides enough entertainment for a few hours.

You can also change music tracks if you want, which I'll be doing soon. So if you for some reason get disappointed in the music, swap to your own. The provided soundtracks are nice, but sometimes the fast(ish) beats combined with the dungeon monster aspects results in missed beats and dead characters.

I do not have any significant flaws with this game - it provides what it says it will - a different approach to rogue-like dungeon exploring that is enjoyable and not buggy at all (I didn't encounter any bugs while playing). Got it on sale at 50% price or something, but even at full price it would be worth grabbing to play.

Price - fine

Gameplay - fun

Bugs - None found while playing

Soundtrack - Sometimes not to my taste, but irrelevant when you're trying your best to survive in a dungeon. All tracks are enjoyable for playing.

reviewText:
Ever since I played Binding of Isaac, I've never found a game to replace it. I enjoyed many rogue-likes, but haven't had the desire to continue them. This is easily the closest I've gotten to finding a second Binding of Isaac. When I first saw this game, two things motivated me to buy it. The reviews and the originality. Neither have lied to me. This game is excellent quality, with very nice pixel graphics, brilliant soundtrack and a lot of different possible runs. This game is great fun to play both casually and seriously. This game reminds me of many games I've played in the past and I feel was directly inspired by those games.
The upgrades and items feel like the Binding of Isaac.
Getting gold from enemies and using diamonds to buy permanent upgrades feels like Rogue Legacy.
The shop and being able to kill the shopkeeper feels like Spelunky.
And the rhythm based gameplay feels like Audiosurf.

I would definitely love to play a lot more of this game and so far I definitely recommend it to rogue-like fans.

reviewText: Crypt is a game I admittedly bought pretty much exclusively for Danny B's soundtrack. The music in this game is fantastic. So much so that I bought the game for PS4 as well. But the gameplay is extremely difficult. It's randomly generated, but extremely based on enemy patterns. There's very little room for error, and each run can end in the blink of an eye. It's a game I really want to get better at, if only because it's so unique. If you put a bit of practice into learning each of the enemy's patterns, it is incredibly rewarding to beat each floor, especially for the first time. It's certainly not a game for everyone, but it's a game that you will enjoy if you spend a bit of time learning how to play it. And even if you suck, you can still enjoy Danny B's beautiful soundtrack.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Brace Yourself Games has developed easily one of the most creative games I've played recently.  Crypt of the Necrodancer combines the roguelike/rhythm genres to produce a dungeon crawler that summons memories of Michael Jackson's Thriller. The skeletons dance, the zombies hop, and the shopkeepers sing as you navigate through the floors of the crypt

It plays similarly to classic turn based style roguelikes, except that the turns happen on the beat of the music.  You will find yourself hopping back and forth to the beat, dodging enemy attacks, and waiting for the perfect moment to strike.  The soundtrack is great, but you can play using your own music instead if you wish.  There is also an easier difficulty setting specifically for playing the game on a dance pad.  It makes me wish I still had a DDR pad lying around, I'd love to give it a try.

The parallels with classic roguelikes do not end with the turn based combat/movement system.  The floors, the contents of treasure chests, shop items, and even boss order are all randomly generated.  The game is also very challenging, quite possibly challenging enough that some players won't enjoy it if they don't like difficult games.  There are several features available to the player to mitigate the challenge.  As you play you will unlock the ability to start at each zone, buy items before entering a zone, and practice against enemies in a risk free environment.

The only criticism that comes to mind about the game is the small number of zones.  There are four zones, and each zone has three stages.  The amount of content reminds me of some NES games.  Many old NES titles could be completed in less than an hour, but took much longer due to the learning required to play successfully.  While I don't feel like there are as many zones as there could have been, they did include ten playable characters.  The characters all have very different styles of play and allow for a solid level of replay value.

Crypt of the Necrodancer is a lot of fun, but I think many players should be wary.  Prospective buyers may be lured in by the cute visuals and awesome soundtrack but miss an important fact about the game.  Necrodancer, at its heart, is a challenging turn based roguelike.  I've played through and finished quite a few games that most would consider to be hard.  This one is tough.  According to  Steam's global gameplay stats, 7.2% of players manage to finish the fourth zone as the main character.  If you're down for a challenge though, you'll have a great time.  I've certainly had a lot of fun with it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As i am writing this please keep in mind this is from the early alpha build so there may be many things yet to be added into the game in the near future.

This game is a really good mix of rhythm meets rouge-like rpg, when you begin you have little on you and can only move when the beat hits the sweet spot (or something like that), and as you go deeper into the Crypt, or zones (whatever you prefer), you will meet stronger monsters and newer upgrades, all of which have a unique take of gameplay. Please also note that you will die a few times on your first try but thats ok, when you die you have a chance to spend any gathered diamonds on upgrades or extra items found in chests and then try again. The Crypts/zones are always randomised meaning not every run will be the same, some will be easy as in the exit is right in front of you, other times you would need to fight through a mini-army to exit the place and will bring many challenges for you to face. At the end of each Crypt/zone, ussually on the forth floor, you will face one of three bosses, all of which brings an interesting take to battle.

And if you get board with the in-game soundtrack (no idea why since the merchants singing is quite fun) you can always add your own music and try get through with your own beats.

So far the alpha has three Crypts/zones with the forth in the making still, but what i've seen the game is really good and i would recommend this game to anyone for how fun its turned out to be.

Personally i give this game a 9/10 (c^_^c)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best music around, coupled with the best music integration since Audiosurf, wrapped nicely into a roguelike dungeon crawler with plenty of depth.
My biggest complaint is that there aren't any extra songs past the default for each level. You can have the game play any song you load, but the ingame music is so perfect that I wish they made more to choose from.

RECOMMENDED for people who like dungeon crawlers or rhythm games.
ESPECIALLY RECOMMENDED for people who like both.
LESS RECOMMENDED for people who dislike permadeath. Everything can be countered, but you'll die a lot of times figuring out how.

reviewText:
The game is only part of it. Holy crap, this soundtrack... Sometimes, something comes along with a gimmick that you love. I love Freddie Merchantry. I sing along with him.

Pros
Genuinely unique rhythm based roguelike.
Amazing soundtrack (Jules tracks aren't my fav but they're still good)
You can use a dance pad. A freaking dance pad.
Base game has lots of options to change gameplay (upgrades, janitor, characters), workshop content goes even farther.
Great artwork and sound.

Cons
Difficulty ramps up to 11 after completing the majority of the story, Aria is quite difficult.
Sometimes you want to play a game, but you're distracted or feeling out of it so your rhythm or skill is off. This is one of those games you can't really play in those times.
The initial difficulty curve of playing a roguelike to rhythm may put off some players. (Bard is here to help! Play him to the beat, stop moving when you need to think about your movement.)

I fully recommend getting this game and its soundtracks for full price or discount. It's completely worth it, discounted or not, fan of rhythm games or roguelikes or not, player of indie games or not. I have 27 hours played, but by now well over 200 hours listening to the music from this game.

reviewText:
With the surge in popularity of roguelikes, it was an eventuality that developers would need to do something other than merely make another punishing dungeon crawler like the original Rogue. While there have been many grand takes on the formula by entrants like Rogue Legacy, FTL, and Nuclear Throne, the last concept I was expecting was a roguelike crossed with a rhythm game. I wondered how this mashup would even work, but it turned out that the answer was quite simple; you just press the arrow keys in time with the music’s beat while traversing floors of a dungeon. Simple premise, but Necrodancer is deviously challenging because of its rhythmical movement, even if it can suffer from incredible roguelike luck.

Dance Dance Revolution meets a dungeon crawler is the quickest and easiest way to define the game. Both the enemies and your movements are tied to the music’s beat, where trying to move on an offbeat will result in an awkward hop in place, and skipping a beat will act as a ‘passed turn’, both dropping your combo. Most enemies have a specific pattern or interaction with the beat, like how skeletons will raise their arms for one beat before moving forward on the following one, or how minotaurs will charge in a straight rhythmic line upon direct sight. Learning these patterns and quirks will let you dance around enemies, and pulling out deft, tactical evasions of enemy mobs never fails to be incredibly satisfying. Items and equipment are available to be discovered or purchased (via a rather vocal and potentially homicidal shopkeeper), including weaponry like longswords that supply an extra square of attack range, boots that let you walk across hazards without a care, rings that bestow various effects like increasing the amount of gold dropped by enemies, spectacles that will let you see what treasure you’ll get from chests and other containers, and other fun utilities. Some loadouts of equipment are more preferable than others, and gathering them becomes a priority in order to make later sections laughably easy. No need to worry about lava or ice when you can just float above the floor! No need to worry about health when you have a blood bow that lets you kill enemies from afar and replenish your health! There are trade-offs between items and gear of course and your ‘this is the run’ loadout will no doubt vary from my own, but once you get an optimal loadout, the game’s later challenging sections become trivial save for boss fights. On the flip side, poor luck resulting in less than ideal loadouts can also occur, and raw player skill can only go so far in some cases.

The challenge in Necrodancer primarily comes from how the enemies never -ever- falter in their timing and movements with the music; The player however can (and will, on your first few attempts) make mistakes, thus making a missed beat punishing or potentially run-ending - Not to mention you lose your gold multiplier from being struck by an enemy. Many roguelikes require situational and environmental awareness in order to avoid losing a run, but Necrodancer demands auditory awareness on top of it all, what with how the music is your means of moving. Thankfully the developers included a visual aid of a heart that beats with every beat, as well as scales that close in on the heart to cue you on when movement or attacking is possible, which is both kind and intelligent on their part. I cannot list the number of times I’ve panicked and had to look at the heart beat in order to get back on rhythm. The music doesn’t last forever however, and if you’re still on the dungeon floor before the song ends and you don’t reach the exit, you’ll automatically be ejected to the next floor. Also as a kind gesture there’s a bestiary that lets you practice against encountered enemies to study their patterns and traits - Considering the later difficulty, these aids help balance the field.

Necrodancer had more characters and modes of play added during its period in early access, like dance mat support, a cooperative mode, and even a custom track function to let you jive around dungeon floors with your own music. The core game doesn’t really change, it simply becomes modified with the various characters and different rules. There’s even a puzzle mode that gives you a floor to tackle using specific items and strategies that quickly becomes head scratching, and of course included is a daily seed that gives all players the same dungeon to take on and go for a high score. Once you get a solid grasp of the game and can get successful runs frequently, these various ways to play improve the longevity of a game that would’ve otherwise been rather short and easy to gleam over.

Your purchase for Crypt of the Necrodancer will primarily rely on whether or not you enjoy the soundtrack; if you don’t, chances are you’re not going to have a good time. Rhythm games can only be so enjoyable if the soundtrack doesn’t sit well with the player, and in my case I’m a fan for most of Necrodancer’s tracks. Danny Baranowsky’s composition is full, vibrant and seldom with any musical downtime, which lends a very active listening experience to the game; for a game where the combat and movement is based on musical beats, having any song be boring or lacking instrumentation would result in dull gameplay. The backing synth for many of the tracks end up giving the soundtrack an almost gothic/horror feel but doing so within its techno/rocking manner. Of course, that’s when you discover later on that there are not one but -two- remixed soundtracks in later sections of the story mode, with the first striking chords of a laser disco and the second more grounded in reality with heavier, nastier rock. All three soundtracks have been uploaded to YouTube if you want to judge for yourself, which is advisable homework when it comes to purchasing rhythm games.

Necrodancer’s strengths lie in its longevity, challenge and gimmick; like many roguelikes the difficulty does become somewhat trivial once you are knowledgeable of its components and mechanics. That said, the demands the game makes of the player ensures that you can know what items work well together and can dance around enemy patterns easily, but it all means nothing if you can’t execute tactfully. Back up this challenge with fantastic music and multiple ways to play, and you get a roguelike that is both satisfying and incredibly enjoyable.
