reviewText:
Crypt of the Necrodancer is definitely one of the most unique roguelike games I’ve ever played, with the added bonus of actually resembling rogue instead of using roguelike as another term for “permadeath without saves”.  You play a family of musicians (or a motley crew of side-characters) determined to unlock the mystery of the magical lute and defeat the Necrodancer, a cursed necromantic bard.

True to its name, you “dance” around each level by moving in tune to the rhythm meter at the bottom of the screen. Each level has its own tune and rhythm and the game steadily increases the pace as you progress. Keeping in tune with the music while vanquishing enemies will net you a higher multiplier which increases the amount of gold you find, in addition to enhancing certain special items found throughout the crypt. Failing to keep to the beat will cause your multiplier to go down and may also prevent you from moving. Since the monsters in the game also move to the beat, they will eventually close in on you to attack and you cannot stand still to “pause” the action (unless you’re playing the bard character).

I found the soundtrack for CotN to be excellent and very diverse. Each level’s song fits its theme pretty well and there are a few tracks that are instantly catchy. The shopkeeper in each level will also sing along with the music, giving a clue to his location, and all of the monsters are either music-themed or have a name alluding to some musical term or instrument, adding an extra layer of detail to this thoroughly polished game.

There really aren’t any faults with this game that would prevent any fan of rogues from picking it up (playing as Aria is extremely hard though) and, even if you’re not normally into games in this genre, the learning curve is very fair. This game is worth picking up even at its original cost, though if you can catch it at the average sale price of $5 it’s quite a steal!

reviewText:
Completionists, stay away.  There are things that are practically impossible to obtain.
Roguelike purists, also stay away.  The game mechanics aren't extremely deep.

Otherwise?  As long as you can tap to a metronome (or at least learn to) and do enjoy action, I highly recommend this game.

Crypt of the NecroDancer, at its core, is a rhythm-based action with roguelite and dungeon crawler elements.  People have compared this game to games such as Faster Than Light and Spelunky; I really enjoyed the former and felt iffy about the latter, and after 350+ hours, I don't know if I can really stop playing NecroDancer just yet.

It's very easy to pick up and understand the core gameplay; one or two local players act to the beat (with only the arrow keys), and everything else responds to your movements on the same beat, allowing you to plan for the next beat.  Getting dropped into the first zone after the tutorial level, you're introduced to a small variety of items, learning about this and that, buying and picking up things to figure out what your favorites are, and dealing with a small variety of enemies.  Items definitely make things easier, but it's absolutely possible to finish everything and low% a run with only default gear.

(By the way, if you want to have a sense of genuine curiosity, go into the options and disable show item hints".)

And once you inevitably die
date: it's not so bad.  There's almost always a way out of whatever predicament you managed to get yourself into
recommended: and you sensibly chuckle at it and figure you'll do better next time.\n\nYou slowly progress
hoursPlayed: saving a few unfortunate NPCs from cages
voteText: buying new things with diamonds and slowly expanding the pool of items you get to find and use during runs.  You finally manage to get the boss down
helpfulPercent: start to learn why Cadence is in this dungeon of dance
votesHelpful: and then you're back to square one
votesTotal: figuring out the patterns in the completely new world that is Zone 2.  And you work through it
votesFunny: because holy crap is that Danny Baranowsky soundtrack fantastic and motivating.\n\nAnd you keep at it.  Some things change completely
commentsCount: some things don't
column16: and some things get flipped upside-down and force you to change tactics.\n\nOccasionally
column17: you take a break from Cadence and pick up a different character.  Oh yeah
column18: there's other ways to play the game in Zone 1 again
column19: and some new strategies for enemies you've seen before.  All the normal characters are interesting to work with in their own way.\n\nOnce you feel that you've finished the important stuff
column20: a variety of things open up.  Score runs?  Speedruns?  Sure thing
column21: try to see how well you can do on the boards and in the daily challenge runs.  Low%?  Go for that
column22: if you want to.  In terms of replayability
column23: you get about as much as Spelunky -- everything generally stays the same
column24: but for some reason the variations between runs always gets you coming back for more.\n\nMods are a thing
column25: to some extent.  At the very least
column26: many resources can be replaced and custom levels are supported and supported through Steam Workshop.  That's about it
column27: though; there's no way to add in completely new items and content just yet.\n\nRemember what I said about completionists?  Yeah
column28: if you want to 100% this game legitimately
column29: forget about it.  The developers added in a character that even they think is impossible.  There's absolutely nothing except bragging rights and an achievement to gain from completing a run as said character (unlike in
column32: so you're not missing out on too much otherwise.\n\nIt's been great watching this game only get better from Early Access; Brace Yourself Games has been nothing less than incredible with regular development and responsive to the community.  If you haven't been driven away from reading this yet
column33: it's absolutely worth more than the $15 that it's listed for."

reviewText:
Crypt of the NecroDancer review
After 200 hours of playtime I think it is finally the time to do a review of Crypt of the NecroDancer... so lets get started

Crypt of the NecroDancer is a Rythm based Rouge-like, so If you like the awesome soundtrack and don`t mind restarting from the beginning, then this would be the perfect game for you.

+Great Soundtrack by DannyB (Also did music for Meatboy etc.), A_Rival and FamilyJules7x
+Graphics - They fit the game really good (Dancing skeletons too)
+Easy contols (You only have to use 4 arrow keys, but you can bind the button combos to other buttons too)
+Contoller/Dancepad support
+Highly skill based (You can beat the game without picking up any items)
+Awesome Shopkeeper
+++ Finally beating that boss you never beaten before

-Getting into the game, as you have to learn the enemy pattern, get into the beat etc.


Crypt of the Necrodancer gets a solid 9.5/10 from me :P

btw... only game you can play with 1 hand  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

reviewText: Time and time again, Danny Baranowsky proves to us why he is the king of indie game music, and for this rogue-like rhythm based game, it's like bread and butter.  Moving to the beat of the music with four buttons; up, down, left, and right.  This is a very simple concept, but very challenging when it comes to execution, due to the amount of concentration required while playing it in order to not get frazzled.  You can pick up items, money, and consumables to take on your journey to reach the end of the game through multiple fun and challenging levels with multiple characters that have a variety of gameplay styles.  In the end, however, it comes down to the music, something in that rhythm games require great music, and that's what Danny whips up for us, along with remixes from A_Rival and FamilyJules7X, which bring us full immersion of the game seamlessly.  All in all, this is on the top of my list of games I recommend to play, because nothing can beat the beat of this game.

reviewText:
Really great game. Just totally solid from every vantage point. Any review that places this game below at least a 90 in score on Metacritic is either using a 5 star system and doesn't grant half stars or doesn't appreciate the nuances of the gameplay / the difficulty of the game.

There is a large breadth of mechanics (there are tons of aspects of play like exploration, timing, resource management, risk/reward, etc) but all of which are approachable. The real startling thing is they have incredible depth and learning the nuances of each one give a decent advantage to the player (spotting loot in wall tiles, having perfect rhythm/decision making while swarmed in constant fractions of seconds, learning to love glass items, when to use a long-hit vs wide-hit weapon, etc). I love roguelikes but rarely find the types that I REALLY love, particularly those that emulate a style of gameplay similar to NetHack while not having any one aspect be broken. The amazing soundtracks on top of a game which is already very easy to appreciate on its own merits is just icing on top of the cake.

The difficulty is fine, in spite of a few claims otherwise. Dancepad mode is available for those who need slightly easier play. Altering the music can also allow for slower gameplay too. Hell, there's a character where you can avoid the beat mechanic entirely and which is very obviously there for players to train and get better, get a purer roguelike experience, or just clear the zones as quickly as possible. ANY review that bashes the game for not being easy in the main mode despite the many attempts by the devs to give easier options is just feeding into the mindset that games with hard base difficulty are bad. It's not only not fair but it's also greatly hindering games with permadeath and large death penalties from being developed. Hell, even I can't beat clear the second zone of Spelunky but I can still appreciate it.

The only criticism of this game that I found fair was that unlocking the full story requires beating all four zones with three different characters, the last of which is a hardcore player character (one missed beat or any damage and you die and have to restart the zone). With vanilla gameplay, even knowing the game VERY well it borders on being a slight bit unreasonable. Bottom line: if you're not the kind of person who complains about how hard and punishing a /ROGUELIKE/ can be and if you're willing to put in enough time to appreciate the depth of mechanics then you'll love Necrodancer.

Get the game. Love it and be a casual player if you'd like. It's perfectly made for that too. But hopefully you'll join in the more competitive scene and see how far the rabbit hole really goes. It could certainly use some action and the game can absolutely support it.

Best of luck unlocking Coda.

reviewText:
Crypt of the NecroDancer review
After 200 hours of playtime I think it is finally the time to do a review of Crypt of the NecroDancer... so lets get started

Crypt of the NecroDancer is a Rythm based Rouge-like, so If you like the awesome soundtrack and don`t mind restarting from the beginning, then this would be the perfect game for you.

+Great Soundtrack by DannyB (Also did music for Meatboy etc.), A_Rival and FamilyJules7x
+Graphics - They fit the game really good (Dancing skeletons too)
+Easy contols (You only have to use 4 arrow keys, but you can bind the button combos to other buttons too)
+Contoller/Dancepad support
+Highly skill based (You can beat the game without picking up any items)
+Awesome Shopkeeper
+++ Finally beating that boss you never beaten before

-Getting into the game, as you have to learn the enemy pattern, get into the beat etc.


Crypt of the Necrodancer gets a solid 9.5/10 from me :P

btw... only game you can play with 1 hand  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crypt of the Necrodancer is incredibly fun. Don't go into it looking for a deep roguelike, at least at this stage of development the actual roguelike aspects are fairly rudimentary and simplistic, but the way that the rhythm game aspects integrate with the core gameplay make it brilliant. The combination is impossibly fun. It's easy to learn but difficult to master and has a fairly large level of polish even in early access, nice pixel art, and a fantastic soundtrack. If you think that you'll enjoy it then you almost definitely will, CotN is as good as it promises to be and better.

Just don't go into it expecting a deep, complex, strategic roguelike, for that you're much better off picking up a copy of Wazhack. My only complaint is that (playing with a controller), I find it difficult to press the button combinations required to use items without breaking my combo, and simultaneously too easy to activate them accidentally well moving around. Overall, though, Crypt of the Necrodancer is well worth picking up, and hopefully it will get even better as it continues development.

Early Access Review

Game goes to BSOD when launching on my Windows XP DDR-Machine PC with two Cobalt Flux Dance Pads...
The PC does meet and exceed the system requirements...
I really want to play this... Please message me if there's a fix, but for now I can't fully enjoy this game as it doesn't work on my DDR Rig and I just can't have as much fun playing it with a keyboard...

It is definitely a great idea, and lots of fun, but I cannot recommend it for the all the people out there like me that have a dedicated Stepmania build that hasn't been updated in a while. By all means the game should be able to run fine. I've commented on the forums and if I'm helped out, I will defintely play through the game and give it the review it deserves.

EDIT: I've been using GlovePIE to play this game with Wiimotes with my friends on the huge TV and it's really great fun. I'll post my configuration on the forums. Still no DDR pads, though. Hopefully it'll get straightened out soon; the developers have been talking to me and trying to help out, and that's all I could ever ask for. Really a shame I got so many downvotes on my prior review, I wasn't trying to be an asshat or anything, but it's very frustrating when you buy a game and spend hours trying to get it to work with no success. I'm sure we've all been there.

Anyway, tl;dr: AMAZING GAME, BUY IT IF YOU LOVE RHYTHM GAMES OR CLASSIC ROGUELIKES

That game is fun to play but hard to master. The music, by Danny Baranowsky, is amazing and it's not that hard to find the right beat to play.
You have to move and attack to the beat of the music. You also have one music per level, and one music per boss.
Plenty of items, huge replayability, Hardcore and speedrun modes, and you can play with a dance pad!

Now, I need one.
This game is awesome, and for an early alpha access, it's really promising and it gives you tons of contents.

Oh, and if you wanna play your music, you can!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is phenomenal. It gives a full roguelike experience but with a unique twist - all movement and actions must be done in sync with the background music. It really is, in effect, a cross between a classic roguelike and a rhythm game such as DDR or osu!

This is more than just a gameplay gimmick. The entire game relies deliberate consistent movement and fast thinking. All enemies have very predictable attack patterns but that hardly makes the game easy. When you have to contend with several different enemies and traps on the screen at once the difficulty can get very challenging, especially in the later levels.

Like all roguelikes, you, as a player, get exponentially better with game experience and knowledge. At first even the earliest floors of the dungeon may seem impossible, but as you start getting faster at processing your situation and taking advantage of your resources, you're able to delve deeper and deeper into the crypt with less effort. Eventually you may find even the nastiest enemies have no chance against your well timed steps. The skill ceiling is so high it's actually possible to beat all consecutive areas without taking damage using the starting weapon. In fact, there is a character and achievement for doing just this.

The best part is that it's all just so satisfying. Not only does everything about this game feel well thought out and balanced, it's hard to express just how good it feels to take all of your actions in time with the music. Every living (or unliving) thing in the dungeon is literally dancing or bobbing its head in sync with the rhythm and it's all just so.. fun! Did I mention the soundtrack is awesome? The soundtrack is awesome.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Inventive mashup of the roguelike/rythm game genres. Most innovative game I have played in a long time. If you think you will enjoy this game, I would definitely recommend it.

Amazing soundtrack!
Heaps of replay value
Challenging gameplay which rewards skillful execution & game knowledge
Items are really well balanced and there are very few (if any) totally useless items
The different weapons are varied and fun to use
There aren't many items that radically change how you approach the game from a tactical standpoint more of a mechanical/execution standpoint
Balanced learning curve
Range of characters that vary in difficulty/playstyle
Pixel art may seem a little over-done in the indie genre but it is very well executed in this game and suits the tone/atmosphere
Devs are adding a lot of content during early access
Minor issues
If you are looking to play the game with your own music, the interface for adding your own music is not well suited for exploring a large music directory
The default controller mapping is not great but it does support custom control mapping for controllers

reviewText:
Ahh, Necrodancer, a wonderful mix of fun and utter frustration!

This game has one hell of an interesting concept - Roguelikes are a ton of fun, if a little frustrating, and rhythm games which I love playing overall because the selection of music is great. This one has 3 artists, all of which are great, and flow with the story and game perfectly.

The selection and designs of the characters are also incredible, you got Cadence, who's the good ol' main character, Melody, who is a ton of fun to wreck with her Golden Lute, Aria who is essentially the Lost and ♥♥♥♥in' frustrating, and many more characters. (My favourite is Dove because she's ♥♥♥♥ING ADORABLE). While these characters are great, I'd love to see remixes for each character rather than just Melody and Aria, that'd make it much more fun to do other characters.

The gameplay is also great, where each movement and action you make must be to the beat of the music and the enemy designs are great too, as they all have patterns to the beat. This is even more fun as you can put your own songs in, and most of the time the music and beats sync perfectly!

This really is a great game, and the world needs more games like these :D

reviewText:
You ever been listening to music while walking down the street and subconsciously (or consciously, I don't judge) timed your steps to the beat of the music?

Crypt of the Necrodancer is like that, except when you ♥♥♥♥ it up somebody stabs you and you lose your coin multiplier bonus. But that's okay, because there are about a dozen different weapons - not counting their materials modifiers, which multiplies that by six - that you can use to just stab them right back.

Four zones, each with their own surprises and mechanics, enemies with varied movement patterns that make the game feel like chess on a really short timer, really ♥♥♥♥♥in' awesome music, and a shopkeeper who sings along to it! ON TOP OF THAT, there are a few reasons to try and replay the game, including more story and unlockable characters.  I mean, you know, if replaying it for the sake of playing it wasn't enough.

Oh yeah, and if you get sick of the music (pfft) you can add your own music. Add some metal, give yourself a heart attack, it's great fun!

Honestly, I'd recommend this game to anyone and everyone who would listen. It's that good. If you're on the fence, get it. If you like roguelikes, get it. If you like rhythm games, get it. If you like both roguelikes and rhythm games, for the love of god, GET IT.

reviewText:
If you haven't bought this already, buy it.

Pros:

The dungeons are different every time.

Tons of characters with very different playstyles (ex the default character has to move to the beat, another one can move to his own beat, one more has infinite bombs, etc.)

The music will get you. I literally cannot get the music out of my head.

Pretty easy to understand. You only use the arrow keys.

Daily Challenge (if that's your thing). Every day a random dungeon is set up and you get one run to score as high as possible. There's a global leaderboard.

Pop in your own music and play to its beats.

Cons:

If you don't like rhythm games, well you won't like this.

It is very VERY hard at first. You meet lots of enemies who each have their own movement and attack patterns. You will probably die a lot, and it can be frustrating. There are a lot of items that can make the game either a (relative) breeze or very hard if you don't have them.
I don't really know if it's a con or not, but it was frustrating.

End of list.



TL;DR

This is my GOTY.

reviewText:
A seriously creative and fun take, on a generic dungeon crawler. Really addictive.

Basicly its a top view dungeon explorer, with a simplicity that reminds of Tibia.

The game's catch, is the fact that you can only move on the music's beat. So its Tibia with Guitar Hero lol

The soundtrack is amazing and unique. Roguelike elements are lacking a bit (not many upgrades on death), but it does have legit concept, that you can unlock boss practice rooms. So yea, its more focused on the player skill instead of player upgrade. Think of this as, Magicite, ftl rogue elements vs Roguelegacy type.

Definetly recommend this game. Its short sure, but just as short as FTL, Magicite, Rain etc.. its totally replayable.

reviewText: This game, just by hearing the type that it is, causes most people to doubt it or wrinkle their nose in confusion. You'd probably think that at first too, it's a dungeon crawler, a rhythm game, and a totally amazing rogue-like game. How does it work? We may never know, but one thing's for certain: a game of this difficulty that's this fun to play deserves more recognition. Like, a lot more. The soundtracks, all three of them, all provide something awesome to the game. I've only had it for a couple days now (yeah, I'm that guy who shows up three hours into the party and acts all cool about it) but that doesn't mean I don't know that this is a game far beyond amazing. Cheers to everyone at Brace Yourself Games, you've created a masterpiece of a game that lots of people will agree is easily one of the best rhythm games out there. I'd go on, but there are too many things that are awesome about this game that I'd probably end up breaking the character limit or something.\nDon't worry Rhythm Heaven, you've always got a special place in my heart\nBut seriously, get this game. It's more than worth the $15, no doubt about it.

reviewText:
Crypt of the Nercodancer is a Dungeon Crawler game mixed in with a Rythem Movement system, as in you have to move to the beat of the song.

the game itself is pretty simple and Really easy to understand, The artstyle is really nice and pretty clean looking aswell and the soundtrack is easily one of the best, all 3 of them, original, EDM and Metal.

There are 10 Characters total, Each every different things, like bolt who moves at double the speed, or Aria who can't get hit or miss a beat (as in dies in 1 hit or missing a single beat.)

There are a bunch of different enemies, which also move to the beat with different patterns which are easy to understand, Each as moving every 2 beats or lunging forward after being hit once or even teleporting the player.

Even if you're someone who isn't great with hearing/listening, there's a guideline sort of thing at the buttom of the screen, which you could use to learn the beat.

Its a great game and i'm amazed the Devs Created this unique game. Easily Recommedable to friends, Especially with the OSTs.

reviewText:
BUY/SALE/PASS: Buy - Feel free to buy at full price.

Crypt of the Necrodancer is a rhythm roguelike dungeon crawler action RPG from developer Brace Yourself Games and publisher Klei Entertainment, and if the description of the game is confusing, don’t worry.  So is the game.  Players are dropped into randomly generated dungeons and tasked to explore as deep as possible without dying.  Death is permanent; when you die, you start from the beginning all over again.

Exploring, fighting, looting, moving, everything is played to the beat of the Danny Baranowsky chiptune soundtrack.  You are likely to die many, many times as you come to learn the various kinds of loot you’ll find and the multitude of enemies to fight.  The good news is that the game is ultimately fun to play and enjoy for players who are into rhythm games and randomized dungeons; the bad news is that getting to that point is layered underneath the frustration of not knowing what to do for the first few hours.  Stick with it long enough, and this game becomes really engrossing to play.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A seriously creative and fun take, on a generic dungeon crawler. Really addictive.

Basicly its a top view dungeon explorer, with a simplicity that reminds of Tibia.

The game's catch, is the fact that you can only move on the music's beat. So its Tibia with Guitar Hero lol

The soundtrack is amazing and unique. Roguelike elements are lacking a bit (not many upgrades on death), but it does have legit concept, that you can unlock boss practice rooms. So yea, its more focused on the player skill instead of player upgrade. Think of this as, Magicite, ftl rogue elements vs Roguelegacy type.

Definetly recommend this game. Its short sure, but just as short as FTL, Magicite, Rain etc.. its totally replayable.

reviewText: This game, just by hearing the type that it is, causes most people to doubt it or wrinkle their nose in confusion. You'd probably think that at first too, it's a dungeon crawler, a rhythm game, and a totally amazing rogue-like game. How does it work? We may never know, but one thing's for certain: a game of this difficulty that's this fun to play deserves more recognition. Like, a lot more. The soundtracks, all three of them, all provide something awesome to the game. I've only had it for a couple days now (yeah, I'm that guy who shows up three hours into the party and acts all cool about it) but that doesn't mean I don't know that this is a game far beyond amazing. Cheers to everyone at Brace Yourself Games, you've created a masterpiece of a game that lots of people will agree is easily one of the best rhythm games out there. I'd go on, but there are too many things that are awesome about this game that I'd probably end up breaking the character limit or something.\nDon't worry Rhythm Heaven, you've always got a special place in my heart\nBut seriously, get this game. It's more than worth the $15, no doubt about it.

reviewText:
I've been addicted to this game since I started playing it. I am not a big fan of rogue-likes in general, but this game is among few rare exceptions.

You have 4 zones to beat, each one contains 3 floors and a boss fight. Every zone has its own theme and enemies. But wait, there's more. The enemies each move to the beat in their own unique pattern, and you have to recognize it and adapt quickly. For example, some enemies might be moving along a scripted path, others try to go for you specifically, some might stay still for 2 beats and then move on the 3rd one, others might move on every beat, and so on. It's all very well done.

During your dungeon crawling, you'll also come across a lot of items of varying degrees of helpfulness. You have healing items, weapons, armour, rings, spells, and even some unusual items. Some can spawn from the start, others require unlocking via collectible diamonds. You can even remove the less useful items from the dungeons via the janitor, so that there's more chances instead for chests to contain the items you find more useful.

There is of course a fair bit of luck involved, as is pretty common with rogue-like games. At times you'll be lucky to find a nice weapon and other useful items early on, other times you'll just be spawning with enemies all around you. It is a very challenging game. You will die a lot. But you do learn to recognize the enemy movement patterns and eventually overcome them.

I also really like the whole light-hearted theme the game is going for. I think the devs pulled it off perfectly. The music is also amazing and will just drag you in to the beat.

In addition to the regular mode with the main character, you also get to unlock several other characters, which seem to have their own unique abilities (for example one of them can only confuse enemies but not kill, another is only able to use bombs, and so on). It all adds an extra challenge for those who want it. You can even go and practice fighting against specific enemies and bosses if you wish.

Great game in general. Highly recommended.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Finally a game where I can play with just one hand!

8.5/10.

Over all Crypt of th NecroDancer embarks into a old school retro dungeon adventure that has you playing to the rythme of the music while ingaging monsters, avoiding traps and completing puzzles. Every map feels different from one another which makes the dungeon experience that much more enjoyable.

You earn gold to buy armor, weapons, magic, food ext... While collecting diamonds to purchase upgrades for your hero at the main menu. You can also unlock different modes and characters to further your dungeon experience.

I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys rythme games, dungeon games or just a quick game that doesn't require you to sit down for over an hour long to complete a map.

This game needs mounts added... I want a Chupacabra mount!


I wonder what kind of things I can do with my other hand while playing this game...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a rogue-like fan, I must admit that this game is really good despite being an early access game because you can't solely rely on your luck but you also really need to have the skills to complete a level.

Pro(s):
- Good gameplay by combining rhythm with dungeon crawler
- Good design with cute pixel art graphics
- High replayability because you can play with different modes and use different characters
- An awesome soundtrack by Danny Baranowsky (I really enjoyed the music)
- And a little bit tricky (like destroying walls with bomb to get a lot of money :P)

Con(s):
- The content is still not that much right now because it's still an early access but the workshop content from the community can fill the gap
- The shortcut/hotkey for the items and spells is hard to be pressed using keyboard maybe it's different when using gamepad or dance pad since I don't have both
- The enemies have fixed pattern and that makes the enemies predictable maybe the enemies need to have combination of patterns to make it unpredictable

I highly recommend this game because it's challenging and fun and it has awesome soundtrack, you really need to buy the soundtrack as well

reviewText:
You *need* this game. Seriously.

EDIT

Now that the final release is out I'm updating my review. Crypt of the Necrodancer is one of those games you really just have to play to understand the hype, and yes this is one of those rare cases where the hype is 100% justified. The game just hits every note perfectly (haha). The gameplay is increadible. Even though the look is familiar, the mechanics are like nothing else out there (which is quite a feat in todays gaming age) but still seems to satisfy on some primal level. It's kind of like speed chess if it were fun. Each enemy moves in a unique pattern and each item effects the behavor of your character. Every move could either result in success or death, but you only have a split second to decide what to do. It really puts you on the edge of your seat especially when playing all zones" mode. Then there's the music. It's amazing. In fact it's so amazing I bought the soundtrack version and uploaded the songs to listen to on my iPod. Of course thats the kind of music we've all come to expect from Danny Baranowsky of Binding of Isaac fame. The great thing about the music is that it makes you dance. Not in the game
date: but in real life. I can't play this game without dancing around with a big grin on my face like a complete idiot. My fiance thinks its hilarious
hoursPlayed: can't stand video games yet still found this game to be entertaining. On top of all that the execution is really what brings it all together. The way the shopkeeper sings to the music
voteText: how the music in the fire/ice stage transitions from metal to classical music seamlessly
helpfulPercent: the quirky sprite animations
votesHelpful: and the light up disco tiles
votesTotal:
it really brings a smile to your face. Its games like these that remind me why I game in the first place. I'm really quite pleased that amidst all the Call of Duty garbage you can still find little gems like this one.

I really can't recomend this game enough! :D

Can't stop dancing/10"

ALPHA REVIEW

The Good
- Great music

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For being creative in the Roguelike genre by adding Rhythm game elements (Dancepad-style controls and gameplay), it's awesome that this game did something out of the ordinary and did it WELL.

New to the game? Don't worry, there's a lot of stuff in the game for beginners, from tutorials to training rooms, to get to up to par with the better players. Wanna challenge yourself? Go right ahead! There's daily challenges, seeded runs, speedrunning, and you can remove items you've unlocked from the dungeon. Like modding games? It's got that too. Just throw some pixel art together and make yourself a new character or two, make a dungeon with the level editor, or edit some of the game's XML data for lulz.

If you've come for a fun time, the soundtrack, got a recommendation, or to introduce yourself to Roguelikes, you won't be disappointed. Just keep in mind, this game doesn't throw punches. The enemies are tough and there are a lot of them. They do however follow patterns, so try to learn them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So addictive. A lot of the enemies move in ways similar to chess moves. The protagonists' attacking style (i.e., the whip weapon, follows the formation of a knight in chess). My personal favourite is the blood whip or the blood raper. XD

The music is unbelievable and makes me want to dance.

reviewText:
For me - who plays games of all sorts (Total War, Civ V, Terraria, Mount & Blade, Don't Starve, Age of Wonders 3, Super Meat Boy, Binding of Isaac (Rebirth), etc.) - I can easily say this: This game is the most charming, most addicting, most playable and enjoyable, and has the ♥♥♥♥ing BEST OF THE BEST soundtrack(s) of all games I've ever played.

Sure it has its flaws: it's harder than Dark Souls... on lag! But damn, difficulty doesn't affect the player if the game is really fun to play ^^

Even though I only have played it for a total of 12h I can still say: this is my favourite drug to use for both a fast or slow game. Just hold the rhythm and dance for your life - weither you use keyboard, controller or dance pad: dance to the rhythm

reviewText:
Twelve hours so far and this game is being incredibly fun! It's very casual if you just want to spend time, but at the same time you actually have a lot of progress the more you play the game.

You pick up diamonds that let you buy upgrades, so everytime that you play the game, you're having a bit of progress and just wasting some minutes on a casual game. Also, the sound beat based game mechanics are insane! I highly recommend the game!

68 hours edit: this game went from a simple casual to a huge challenging game. Once you beat the game with the main character, you start to unlock new and even harder characters, and the challenge keeps going on! It's insane how the developers made it fun, creative and challenging.
